DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF THE HONOURABLE SIR HOWARD BEALE, KBE, QC

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I advise honourable senators that on 17 October the Hon. Sir Howard Beale, former member of the House of Representatives, died. I move the following motion of condolence:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death of the Honourable Sir ( Oliver) Howard Beale, member of the House of Representatives for the Division of Parramatta from 1946 till 1958, Minister of the Crown from 1949 till 1958, Ambassador to the United States of America from 1958 till 1964, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

Sir Howard Beale died last night at the age of 85. He was born in Tamworth in December 1898, the son of a Methodist Minister whose family had come to Australia in 1838. He was a graduate in Arts and Law from the University of Sydney and was called to the Bar in 1925, where he established his own practice. From 1942 to 1945 he served as a sub-lieutenant with the Royal Australian Naval Reserve. In the general election of 1946 he was elected for the seat of Parramatta, New South Wales, succeeding Sir Frederick Stewart of the then United Australia Party. His maiden speech, on 14 November 1946, displayed his lifelong interest in international affairs. In 1949, after Sir Robert Menzies was elected to power, Sir Howard Beale commenced service as a Minister in the Government and remained in that capacity until his retirement from Parliament in 1958. During that time he served as Minister for Information, Minister for Transport, Minister for Supply and Minister for Defence Production. He resigned from the Parliament and the Ministry on 10 February 1958 following his appointment as Ambassador to the United States of America, a position he was to hold until 1964 .

Sir Howard Beale was well regarded as a speaker both within this Parliament and elsewhere. After his retirement in 1964 he was made Regents Visiting Professor at the University of California in 1966, Regents Visiting Professor at the University of Wisconsin in 1967 and 1969 and President of the Arts Council of Australia from 1965 till 1968. His memoirs were published in 1977, and I understand that they are a fascinating recollection of the history-making events of his time. As will be seen from what I have said, he was a man of wide-ranging interests and concerns who served this country in a great variety of capacities. He is survived by his wife, Lady Beale, and a son, Julian. On behalf of the Government and the people of Australia I extend our sympathy to his family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the remarks made by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) with respect to the late Sir Howard Beale. I think it is appropriate that the Senate should pay tribute to the life and work of a very distinguished Australian. Sir Howard Beale, in his early years, had a career in the law. He had a career in the armed forces during the Second World War. He had a career in the national Parliament. He had a career as an ambassador and, more latterly, he had a career as a businessman. I think that in the great variety of his life there was something that many of us would wish to emulate, Mr President, and many of us would like to rank our achievements with his.

SPEECH.PARA: Sir Howard Beale was a very significant figure in the formation and success of the Liberal Party. He was a member of the first New South Wales State Executive of the party which was formed by Mr Menzies and he became a Minister when the Liberals came to office in 1949. His appointment as Ambassador to the United States was a recognition of his life long interest in foreign policy which was the subject of his maiden speech to the House of Representatives. Sir Howard Beale retained an interest in national and political affairs for many years after his retirement from active public life. He contributed from time to time to the pages and letters columns of our newspapers on matters as diverse as the growing welfare payments burden, meat substitution and political tactics engaged in by his successors to the non-Labor benches in this Parliament.

He was in my view a man of keen perception with a great sense of history and a good sense of perspective. I recall something which would perhaps interest the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes). Sir Howard Beale did enter the public debate when Sir Phillip Lynch's comments on pensions paid to wealthy members of the community caused some political furore some years ago. In his writings at that time he recalled a warning by Sir Robert Menzies to the Cabinet in 1950 that welfare services could end up imposing a very heavy financial commitment on society as a whole. I note that he came down firmly on the side of a needs based welfare system and canvassed the need for changes to taxation on superannuation and questioned whether Australia should return to an assets or income test system.

I want to inject one brief personal note into my remarks. I had the good fortune to spend a day with Sir Howard Beale in the late 1970s in Athens. My wife and I were there at that time and he returned, I think, from a dig on the island of Rhodes where his wife had undertaken some archeological work. We spent a day discussing Australia and its politics. I was particularly struck by the balance which it seemed to me he had brought to his life. As I said earlier in my comments, I think the range of his achievements is something which many of us would wish to emulate. On behalf of the Opposition I express our sympathy and, I am sure the sympathy of the Senate, to his widow and to his son Julian. I think we should be grateful for the contribution which he made to Australia over a very lengthy period.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to associate the Australian Democrats with this condolence motion and also convey our regrets to Lady Beale and Sir Howard's son. I note briefly that Sir Howard Beale was a well loved and respected member of the community of New South Wales, for which I am a senator. More than that, since his retirement Sir Howard Beale lived and was admired and respected in Leura which is my home town in New South Wales. I would like to associate the Australian Democrats with this motion. We have lost a person of great distinction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to associate myself personally with this message of sympathy to Lady Beale and to Howard's son Julian. It has been my privilege to know Howard Beale since 1946. He died both in the fullness of his years at 84 and in the fullness of his accomplishments. It is true, as both the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) have said, that he was a man who in his life played many parts. They include lawyer, naval officer, parliamentarian, Minister, diplomat, business director and wise advisor. I want to say at the outset that so much of his success, in my view, was due to his admirable choice of life partner, his wife Margery who brought into that partnership dignity, ability, natural talent and a sharing of the duties which served him well in everything he did, both as a Minister and as a diplomat abroad.

SPEECH.PARA: In expressing my sympathy to Lady Beale and to Julian, I want to pay that tribute to the family as well as to the man. I simply remark, in that journey, that I knew Howard Beale as one of the most articulate speakers and debaters in this Parliament in the post-war years. He was a man who had the ability to express ideas clearly and attractively. He carried that ability through to his role as diplomat in America. I was most agreeably pleased to find that the American people found his service there of great credit to him and to Australia. That was reflected afterwards by a continuous association between himself and the American people, and it was reflected by tributes to him throughout the business community of Australia. Very few men were able to journey so widely to play so many parts. On that basis I pay tribute to the work that he had done, but special tribute to his wife and son for their partnership in it.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to:
undermine civil liberties and religious freedoms.
entrench abortion funding and render liable to action hospitals, doctors and nurses who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations.
deny to parents their rights to insist that the school ''community'' provide an environment conducive to the development, including the moral development of their children.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled: should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of the principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Coates (from 66 citizens) and Walters (from 144 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

Whereas the Government of Australia has signed UN Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states the family is the natural and fundamental unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State.
Whereas the terms of the UN Covention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above article 23 (1).

We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women, believing that its implementation would result in the following:
(1) Undue cost to the nation at this time.

(2) The elimination of any sterotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels as described in part 3 Article 10 (C) being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances in childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce with the provision of a network of creches and babycare centres as outlined in Article 11 of the Convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in part 3 Article 10 (C) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation and your petitioners in duty bound to pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Youth Forum: Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth.

Since 1979 over 3,000 young people have participated in youth forum projects. Youth forum has the structure and network necessary to provide young people in New South Wales with the skills, information and opportunity to define, and solve some of their own problems.

Apart from an International Year of the child grant of $15,000 in 1979, youth forum has received no government funding, rather it has utilized a total of $320 ,000, raised from the private sector. Youth forum is in danger of closing in early October if government funding is not secured, and valuable youth skills and resources will be lost to the community.
Youth forum is an existing project which is a perfect vehicle through which the federal government can pursue the objectives of international youth year peace participation and development-in 1985.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should financially support youth forum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Scheyville Airport, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That an airport in the north-western region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.
2. An airport would destory 2,000 households and impose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million people presently unaffected.
3. The cost of an airport in the north-western region is greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close proximity to R.A.A.F. Base Richmond would make operations impractical.
4. It would destory the historic village of Pitt Town, environmentally important wetlands, and their unique adherent wildlife.
5. Your petitioners reject these proposals and call for endorsement of the MANS Committee findings.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:

The Universal Declaration of Human Rights affirms the principle of the inadmissibility of discrimination and proclaims that all human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights and that everyone is entitled to all the rights and freedoms set forth therein, without distinction of any kind including distinction based on sex.

However extensive discrimination against women continues to exist. It is an obstacle to the participation of women on equal terms with men, in the political , social, economic and cultural life of this country. It hampers the growth of the prosperity of society and the family and makes more difficult the full development of the potentialities of women in the service of this country and of humanity.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will act to ratify the convention on the elimination of all forms of discrimination against women.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Giles (from five citizens) and Ryan (from 13 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. that the Tertiary Education Allowance Scheme (TEAS Allowance) has been progressively reducing in real terms throughout the 1980s, and is no longer at an adequate subsistance level.
2. that the situation where the independent TEAS allowance is substantially below the single, no dependant, unemployment benefit is inequitable and not supportable by cost relativities.
3. that the low level of TEAS allowance is detrimental to maintaining the proportion of students currently partaking in tertiary education.
4. that effective immediately the TEAS allowance should be increased to the same level as the single unemployment benefit and thereafter be maintained in line with changes in said benefits.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Non-Government Schools Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Victoria showeth:
That any reduction in Government funding of non-Government schools would seriously affect the quality of the educational services provided and cause financial hardship for many parents.

Your petitioners therefore pray that any change in the funding system for non- Government schools recognises the fundamental right of all children to an equitable share of Government funds for education.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Withholding Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners are concerned about the effects of the withholding tax.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should irrevocably abolish the withholding tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Force Reserves: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That as Mr R. J. L. Hawke has publicly stated;
(1) 'The Defence Force Reserves are the backbone of our nation's defence',
(2) The Defence Force Reserves are a highly economical and viable means of training men and women to serve Australia in times of emergency,
(3) The Reserves are composed of volunteers dedicated to Australia.

Furthermore, we the undersigned recognise that members of the Reserves are required to maintain levels of efficiency at least equivalent to those of the permanent forces, and that members of reserves spend much of their own time and money towards reserve training obligations.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the government recognise the role played by the reserves in serving Australia, that Reserve pays and allowances are already far below the levels for equivalent work in the general workforce, and that therefore the proposed introduction of taxation to the meagre pays earned by members of the Defence Force Reserves is a poor way of saying thank you.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Excise on Grape Spirit
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the 1983 Budget imposition of the excise on grape spirit used in fortifying wine places at risk the future of the fortified wine industry in Australia.
That the requirement to pay the excise within 7 days of the fortification occurring is inequitable.
That the excise will be reflected in increased costs to the consumers of fortified wines of up to 100 per cent and consumer choice will be restricted.
That this will cause reduced fortified wine sales which will result in reduced intake of grapes from grapegrowers.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will reconsider their previous decision and either withdraw this tax or modify its method of applications and collection.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Adult Migrant Education Service
PETITION.PARA: The humble petition of residents of the State of Victoria respectfully showeth:
(1) that temporary salaried and full-time sessional teachers working for Adult Migrant Education Services are disadvantaged in status and security by lack of permanency and
(2) that this disadvantage is reflected in its effect on and implications for multicultural education.
(3) Victoria is particularly disadvantaged as with 30% of national Adult Migrant Education Program it had only one permanent member of staff.
Your petioners therefore pray that:
(1) This imbalance be redressed by providing realistic funding for permanency.
(2) Funding should be used to balance the present inequity of permanent positions throughout Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That your Petitioners are concerned about foreign owned military bases on Australian territory and the entry into Australian waters and territory of foreign warships and aircraft carrying nuclear weaponry. And that the Australian Government should take an active and constructive role in the promotion of a nuclear-free world. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
1. Promote the expression of Australian sovereignty by legislating to bring foreign military bases on Australian territory under the control of the Australian Government.

2. Make it compulsory that the disclosure of weaponry carried by foreign warships and aircraft be given in confidence to the Australian Government prior to a request for entry. And that foreign warships and aircraft that carry nuclear weaponry be banned from Australian waters and territory.
3. Legislate for the cessation of all uranium mining in Australia and its subsequent export.

4. Urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to pose to the Governments of the United States and the Soviet Union that both countries agree to immediately halt the testing, production and further deployment of all nuclear weapons, missiles and delivery systems in a way that can be checked and verified by both sides.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Resources and Energy whether he recalls that, in answering a question I asked him some weeks ago on market prospects for uranium, he quoted a letter written from Total Australia Ltd to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment to support his contention-that is, the contention of the Minister for Resources and Energy-that it was economics not politics which was preventing the development of Australia's uranium deposits. I ask the Minister: Is he aware that the author of that letter has written to the Business Review Weekly disputing the suggestion that his company's position should be interpreted as support for the Government's uranium policy? I ask the Minister whether he has seen the letter which says, in part:

QUESTION.PARA: In our view there will be demand in the late 1980s to justify production from Ben Lomond at that time.
I further ask the Minister whether he accepts the conclusion of the letter published in the magazine's edition of 23 July that:

If a two-year delay in development of the Ben Lomond deposit because of world economic conditions has indeed been seized upon by opponents of uranium mining as a reason for delaying the development of the uranium industry generally, they must be desperately short of arguments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall quoting from a letter from Total. I have not seen the letter published in Business Review Weekly to which Senator Chaney refers; therefore, I am obviously not fully familiar with the details of it. I gather from what Senator Chaney has said that the representative of Total has said that the letter the company had written earlier should not be interpreted as support for Government policy on uranium mining. I have certainly not interpreted it that way. I quoted from that letter in support of the Government view, verified and corroborated from a number of different sources, that the present uranium market is such that contracts cannot be written at prices which would have been acceptable to the previous or the present Federal Government.

ANSWER.PARA: I add that I am currently following up a report which appeared last week that Mr Tony Grey, the Chairman of Directors of Pancontinental Mining Ltd, which has the major, if not the sole, interest in the Jabiluka uranium prospect, has been reported as having said in London that, in fact, the outlook for the world uranium market is even gloomier than had been anticipated a few months or a year ago and that indeed the anticipated demand for the early 1990s might well not materialise until the end of this century. I do not know whether Mr Grey was reported accurately; that is a matter I am having followed up. But, independently, or as a further piece of corroborative evidence, the most recent figures on the deferment and cancellation of nuclear power stations planned in the United States and Europe, in particular, further confirm the Government's judgment made some time ago that not only is the world demand for uranium such that contracts could not be written at prices which would be acceptable to the previous or the present Government, but also, if anything, the indications suggest that the situation in the medium and short term is likely to deteriorate even more than had been previously anticipated.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I ask: Firstly, how seriously does the Government view the threat by Iran to block the Straits of Hormuz; secondly, have there been any discussions by the United States or United Kingdom governments with Australia towards any Australian commitment to a task force to act in the event of such a blockade-if so, what is their nature; thirdly, what actions would be envisaged for such a task force; fourthly, has the Australian Government taken any steps at all at the international or bilateral level to attempt to mitigate the possibility of the closure of the straits; and, finally and specifically, has the Government had any talks with the Iraqi Government, particularly to urge that Government not to provoke this very serious danger by the use of Exocet-type missiles?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously the Government takes seriously any possibility of the Straits of Hormuz being blocked as a result of the Iran-Iraq conflict. I indicated the Government's concern in this respect in answer to a question last week. As to the Press reports that have been circulating to the effect that Australia could be asked to contribute to a naval force in the Middle East if there is an escalation of the war between Iran and Iraq, my brief from the Minister for Foreign Affairs is to the following effect: There has been no discussion with any country of such an Australian involvement. Australia has, however, discussed the situation in the Gulf in general terms with a number of countries and it has expressed its concern in those discussions at the possibility of an escalation of the Iran-Iraq war. Australia has supported calls for a ceasefire in the conflict and negotiations to remove differences between Iran and Iraq ever since the hostilities began three years ago. We hope that both countries will look again at the possibility of a peaceful resolution of the conflict.

ANSWER.PARA: To the extent that that briefing material does not answer the further specific questions that have been put to me by Senator Sir John Carrick, I will seek an early reply from the Minister and advise him accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology. It refers to recent discoveries in medical bio-chip technology whereby paraplegics have been helped to walk and the blind to see. Firstly, can the Minister advise what funding, if any, has been allocated specifically for research of this nature and, secondly, is the Minister of the opinion that there is potential for further development of this kind of technology in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot provide a precise and detailed answer to the honourable senator's question but I must say, first of all, that in the recent Budget the Government made available a specific sum of money for biotechnology research and development. Probably the largest increase in the Budget related to research and development generally and research grants. The Government also made a substantial increase in the level of funding available to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. I should add that the Australian people have a very good record in terms of medical and biomedical technology, and some of the research that has been done in Australia is of world class.

ANSWER.PARA: Some of the so-called sunrise industries about which we hear a lot of talk, but which perhaps do not have as dramatic a representation as we would like, are in the medical technology area. A number of very highly successful Australian companies operating in that area have obtained substantial penetration of world markets. I will refer that portion of Senator Elstob's question referring to specific technology to the Minister for Science and Technology and obtain a fuller answer as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. It refers to a subdivision of land in the rain forest region of Cape Tribulation in Queensland at a place called Cow Bay, just north of the Daintree River. Is the Government aware that much of this large subdivision of more than 4,500 hectares is being sold as one-hectare blocks? I think most conservationists consider that the development of all those blocks would induce the complete destruction of the rain forest with which they are covered. I might say that an inspection I made of that area earlier this year confirmed that belief as reasonable. Is the Minister aware that it has been reliably reported that an attempt by the Douglas Shire Council to restrict this subdivision to a more conservational minimum size per block of two hectares, which indeed at the time was the Council's minimum requirement, was overruled by the Minister for Local Government, Main Roads and Racing in the Queensland Government, Mr Russell Hinze, and that as a result much of the area was subdivided into one-hectare blocks and sales of the estate so far amount to some $4m? Can the Government, through the use of its environmental powers, do something to save what is regarded as one of the most important areas of rain forest left in the tropical area of Australia? Will it investigate the circumstances of the subdivision, including the involvement of Mr Hinze, with the objective of rezoning this region so that the natural rain forest there can be preserved?
—I am not as full bottle as Senator Mason on the details of the subdivision of the rain forest region of Cape Tribulation.
—Senator Ryan knew nothing about this on Thursday.

—I am indebted to Senator Missen. It appears that ignorance is not bliss in this case; it is widely shared. I was not aware that the subdivision approved by the Council had been of two-hectare blocks and that the Minister for Local Government in Queensland had intervened with the result that the subdivision was into one-hectare blocks. I am, of course, familiar, as every other Australian is, with the practice of the Minister for Local Government in Queensland of intervening in these matters. It seems to be part of the present Queensland Government's style. Certainly, I will obtain advice as to whether the Commonwealth has any possibility of influencing events in this matter. But I am hopeful that after 22 October the Commonwealth will be able to influence events much more easily in Queensland with a new Minister for Local Government.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware of the interview broadcast on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio in Tasmania this morning about Medicare? Can he say how representative of the medical profession the person interviewed is, and is his claim true that he is merely continuing the fine tradition of Hippocratic medicine and all he wants is to return to a free market in medicine? The person interviewed stated that private hospitals are half as costly as public hospitals. Perhaps the Minister can explain why this is so. Finally, how close is Medicare to being communist doctrine, as claimed in the interview? What is the doctor concerned really frightened of?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I did read a transcript of an interview this morning on the program Becker's Broadside with Dr Jodhi Menon, who is in fact the President of the General Practitioners Society in Australia. I must say that Dr Menon confirmed all the remarks I made about him and his organisation last week in answer to a question from Senator Hearn. Dr Menon, of course, as Senator Coates pointed out, said that the Australian Labor Party was involved in introducing communist doctrine to this country in Medicare. He also made the same remark, as I understand it, about the Canadian system. He said that what he and his colleagues were doing was following in the finest tradition of the Hippocratic oath which doctors take.

ANSWER.PARA: I make the point that I made last week-that in fact any organisation such as the General Practitioners Society in Australia and any doctors such as Dr Menon who are willing to use patients and to disadvantage patients in order to push their own political views and their own philosophy are in fact not supporting the principles of the Hippocratic oath. They are in fact going directly against them. It is quite clear from reading the answers given by Dr Menon that he and his colleagues are not concerned about their patients. They are concerned about their own pockets. They are not concerned that their tactics will disadvantage many of their patients, including pensioners, because most members of the General Practitioners Society allege at least that they will not bulk bill pensioners. They are disadvantaging pensioners, some of the most vulnerable people in the community.

Dr Menon made many other statements during his question and answer session this morning. He made a great point of the fact that private hospitals are less expensive than public hospitals, but he failed to mention that the facilities that need to be introduced into public hospitals to handle the most severe medical and surgical emergencies and the illnesses that are the most complicated and most expensive to treat inevitably mean that public hospitals are more expensive to run than private hospitals, some of which do not deal with any of these conditions at all. Equally, he claimed that private hospitals in this country receive no assistance from public funds. As Senator Coates and other honourable senators would know, that is quite wrong. There are government subsidies to most of the private hospitals in this community.

I think the whole tenor of Dr Menon's remarks is typical of the remarks made by the General Practitioners Society in Australia and bears no resemblance to the attitude of most responsible doctors in this community which is, in fact, to take the Hippocratic approach and put their patients first. The General Practitioners Society is a very small organisation. It is representative of a small percentage of general practitioners and other practitioners in this community. It does not have the support of the vast majority of medical practitioners. The organisation is maintained by considerable support from certain drug companies which also have reason to oppose the Government. As such, as I said last week, it is an extreme right wing political organisation which is not representative of any organisation which would want to see the standard of medical practice in this country improved.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Further to my question of 22 September concerning the application of the assets test for retired couples on farms, I now ask: How will the Government apply the assets test to the farm home when the older generation farm family still owns the farm but the son or son-in-law is actually working the farm and living either in the farm home while the parents live away from the farm or in a second home on the farm?

—As I think I said to Senator Collard in answer to the question he asked on that earlier occasion, as was the case in the previous assets test or the previous means test which was in place in this country before 1976, there was a need to give special consideration to the very people he was talking about and to farmers in general. In fact, we are doing that now. As a result of discussions with pensioner organisations, members of parliament and other interested groups, we are putting together our proposals which will be discussed this week and next week by the Government as to how we will handle all the assets. The matter of the elderly farmer and his wife who for years have been living on a farm will have to be taken into consideration. It is a fairly common occurrence in the rural community that an elderly farmer does live on a farm but the farm has been run for many years by his son, his son-in-law or other members of the family, often for very low incomes or practically no income at all. In the past the house in which they lived and the curtilage around the house was all that was considered to be exempt, except in special hardship cases. As I think I said in answer to a question on this matter-it may not have been Senator Collard's question-we do not consider that that is sufficient. At the moment we have proposals to extend that. As I do not want to open up unnecessary debate, I assure Senator Collard that before the legislation comes into the Parliament he and other honourable senators will be able to see the proposals which we will finalise in the next couple of weeks and have a discussion on whether they are sufficient.

—Is the Minister for Industry and Commerce aware of recent comments by Mr Robert Paterson, the President of the New South Wales Chamber of Manufactures, to the effect that there has been in the past a lack of Federal policy direction in manufacturing industry? Does the Minister consider that there is a need for, in Mr Paterson's words, 'a coherent long-term strategy for manufacturing industry'? How are the Government's policies directed towards this end?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Paterson's remarks have been drawn to my attention. I share his concern.
—You are not planning an incoherent short term strategy? Surprising!

—It would be tremendous if I could answer the question without the assistance of Senator Chaney. One of the Government's first priorities in manufacturing industry policy was to try-we certainly tried in the Budget context-to get together a number of matters which would constitute a framework for sound medium and long term industry policy development. I agree with Mr Paterson that in the past policy has been incoherent and ad hoc, as he put it. We cannot afford more of the band-aid remedies of the last 20 years involving short term industrial planning, sudden retrenchments and ad hoc decisions. He went on to say, 'Nor are we simplistically arguing for protection for protection 's sake' and that wrangling between the so-called wets and dries was barren, sterile and unable to produce a viable solution. Wrangling between the so-called wets and dries, I notice, is still a current preoccupation of the Opposition. It is a preoccupation which extends not only to industry policy but also into wages policy.

ANSWER.PARA: Since the Government came to office it has taken a number of initiatives in industry policy including a review of the Industries Assistance Commission which it regards as very important. The restructuring of manufacturing industry councils and the Australian Manufacturing Council has been undertaken. Particular initiatives have been taken in respect of two vitally important industries, the steel industry and the motor car industry. A number of other initiatives, taken by the Government in the last Budget, include initiatives taken in the science and technology area with the expansion of a number of programs which are vitally relevant to the future and pattern of development of Australian industry, initiatives taken by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations in respect of training programs and, of course, the prices and incomes policy. All these things are regarded by the Government as essential to the long term health of Australian manufacturing industry, particularly in a time of what, undoubtedly, will be severe restructuring and change.

I think it is important to recognise that any government, faced with the situation of Australian manufacturing industry as it was at the start of 1983, will face severe problems of restructuring and change. Those problems have to be met in a variety of areas, including the areas outside the portfolio responsibility of the Minister for Industry and Commerce to which I have referred. It is a source of a great regret that the previous Government did not tackle some of those issues in the seven years which it had available to it. None of these things was, in fact, attempted by the previous Government. In the foreseeable future, the Government will be looking towards placing less emphasis on tariff measures than it has in the past, but much more on the area of positive industry assistance measures such as improved depreciation and investment allowance provisions which were, of course, brought together in the Budget context to give Australian industry the best cost of capital regime it has had, probably ever. In the general area of government assistance, the Government has already made a number of alterations to the function and capacity of bodies such as the Australian Industry Development Corporation to assist industry with particular restructuring programs. The details of those matters have already been drawn to the attention of the Senate.

I share the concern of Mr Robert Paterson about these matters. The Government's basic view, however, is that it is necessary to get the guidelines and parameters right so that industry has the best opportunity to flourish. In particular areas of concern and in particular industries, the Government is quite prepared to assist on a co-operative basis, as it did in the case of the steel industry and is seeking to do in the motor vehicle industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that the paper from which the Minister has quoted be tabled.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Is the recent statement by the Chairman of the Australian National Line, Mr Bolitho, hinting at safety dangers if a foreign ship joins the Bass Strait run a personal statement or does this statement reflect the Government's view? Is not such a derogatory statement a reflection on some of the world's finest shipbuilding nations, including the world recognised shipbuilding industry of Finland, a country capable of supplying a vessel for the Bass Strait service? Are these scare tactics part of an attempt to keep Tasmania isolated from the mainland and to protect ANL's excessive profits on the Bass Strait service compared with its returns from other services ?
—I will have to take that question on notice.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Defence: What are the implications for defence and security of the large oil find in the Jabiru 1A oil well in the Timor Sea? Are the defence and security implications of a potentially large oilfield in our northern waters likely to differ from those for other off-shore oilfieds, such as those in Bass Strait; and, if so, how?

—The defence of areas containing off-shore oil installations would generally pose additional operational problems for the Australian Defence Force compared with operations to secure oil installations on mainland Australia . These problems have been addressed in planning relating to the Bass Strait and the North West Shelf fields. Generally, however, operations, to state the obvious, become more complex the further off-shore the installations are. Planning for the security of existing off-shore oil and gas fields against the threat of, for example, terrorist attack is assessed to be of national importance. Should the Jabiru find be proved, planning for the security of installations in that area would also assume clearly that level of significance. It will be appreciated that it is not appropriate for either the Minister for Defence or me on his behalf to discuss in any detail the operational concepts and planning relating to the security of vital national installations or potentially vital national installations. I hope that Senator Maguire will be happy with an answer expressed in those necessarily fairly general terms.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security in his own capacity and also in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Health. Is he aware of the significant concern amongst many organisations and individuals involved with the care of the aged about suggestions that the proposed Office of Aged Care be located within the Department of Health? Given recent reports that the Minister intends to split the Department of Social Security into two departments, can the Minister explain the moves to locate the proposed Office of Aged Care under the aegis of the Department of Health and not in the proposed new social or community services department? Can the Minister categorically assure the Senate that this will not now happen?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, Senator Messner and other honourable senators will be aware that it is Australian Labor Party and therefore Government policy that in fact we have an Office of Aged Care. I believe this is a sensible policy. At the moment, accommodation for the aged, nursing homes, hostels, et cetera, are split between the Department of Social Security and the Department of Health with the Department of Health making approvals in principle, the Department of Social Security providing capital expenditure and the Department of Health providing recurrent expenditure. It, therefore, would seem to be sensible to incorporate these functions into an Office of Aged Care. It certainly has been the recommendation of committees in the past that the Office of Aged Care under these circumstances should be in the Department of Health.

ANSWER.PARA: It is also true that in the past I have said that I would expect a government to investigate the possibility of splitting the very large Department of Social Security into a department of income security, say, and a department providing community or human services. This has been a suggestion not only of mine but also of other people who have looked at the administrative arrangements.

I finally make the point that it is not up to me to split the department. Administrative arrangements of this type are a matter between the Prime Minister and the Cabinet and government itself. At the moment certainly there is discussion in the Government, first of all about the establishment of an Office of Aged Care, which is something I certainly agree with, and, secondly, about the development of a department of community services. Whether the Office of Aged Care will go to the Department of Health, to the department of community services or to the Department of Social Security or any other department will depend on discussions and investigations that we make in the future; whether there is a department of community services split off from the Department of Social Security and incorporating those service areas which naturally go together, again is a matter for discussion and investigation.

I am aware that some organisations would prefer the Office of Aged Care not to go to the Department of Health. I suppose there are others who would prefer that it did. I ask Senator Messner to restrain his impatience. This is a matter for discussion within the Government and a matter for investigation, and I am sure that a decision one way or the other as to all these options will be made in the near future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer, but I wonder whether he could be a little more specific about the time.
—We do not believe that we should rush precipitately into such a decision without thinking about it.
—You could have fooled us.

—Senator Walters, that would be the easiest thing to do in this place if I should so wish, but I do not. What I am saying is simply that, in trying to deal with an economy in the state in which your side of the chamber left it, in the position of trying to deal with the sometimes confusing, always bewildering administrative arrangements in which your side of the place left the bureaucracy of this country, we believe that we should sit down, as we have and as we will continue to do, to work out the best plans so that in the future we can have a rational system of administration of community services in this country, a rational system of retirement incomes and a rational system of care for the aged.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy . I ask whether his attention has been drawn to a report in the Canberra Times of 17 October in which the Executive Director of the Australian Mining Industry Council, Mr James Strong, is quoted as criticising the Government's proposed resources rent tax, stating:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . that since the mining industry was already subject to excessive total levels of taxation and other Government charges . . . AMIC is, therefore, totally opposed to any additional taxes or levies.

Can the Minister indicate whether the proposed resources rent tax is an additional tax or whether it is intended as a replacement tax? Will the proposed resources rent tax offer any advantages over the existing mineral taxes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of a report in the Canberra Times yesterday which quotes Mr Strong in terms similar to those used by Senator Childs. I am also aware of an interview on the AM program yesterday between Mr Strong and Pru Goward. I cannot remember precisely all of the question that Senator Childs asked, but the essential part was whether the Government was proposing an additional tax. The answer to that, which I repeat again slowly-unfortunately, I cannot do it in monosyllables; I would like to be able to do it slowly and in monsyllables because apparently it is necessary to say it slowly and in monosyllables before some people actually manage to understand it-is no, the Government is not proposing to place an additional tax. The Government is proposing to replace an existing inefficient form of taxation with an economically superior form of taxation. I would have thought that since I have told Mr Strong that directly, since I have told various representatives of the mining industry that directly, the message ought to have got through by now. Perhaps I should devote some time to attempting to devise a form of words in which it can be stated in monosyllables and then perhaps understood.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to the AM program, the interview itself between Pru Goward and Mr Strong, with one minor exception, was a reasonable interview. The introduction of the program, however, by the program compere Mr Red Harrison was, to say the least, slothful. He referred to a decline in mining industry investment of $500m in the last 12 months and then said that the Government was talking about imposing new taxes. He stated:
The Minister responsible, Senator Peter Walsh, argues that the mining industry ought to pay more than merely corporate taxes--

I was under the impression-I would have thought that the compere of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's AM program might have known-that the mineral industry traditionally has paid more than corporate taxes. If he does not know that it is about time he discovered it. I suggest that he should give more attention to the manner in which he introduces items on AM. With respect to the interview itself, in response to a comment from Mr Strong similar to that quoted in the National Times, Pru Goward said:
The Minister hastens to assure you that it's only to replace existing taxes and not to add an extra one.
I note that the interviewer, as revealed in that statement, was at least better informed-significantly better informed-than the compere of that program. Mr Strong in reply said, inter alia:

If this is to be what is commonly known as a rent tax, then we're not too clear as to why it should particularly apply to the mining industry and not to many other sectors of the economy where similar philosophy could apply.

If that is to be taken at face value, it is indicative-if it is not indicative, it is prima facie evidence-that at least Mr Strong does not understand the concept of economic rent. Manufacturing industry can be infinitely replicated at similar or identical costs; extractive industries cannot. It could be argued from that, of course, that a rent tax ought to apply to agriculture or a rent tax ought to apply to people in very specialist service industries such as highly talented surgeons, highly talented musicians and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. This has been a very long answer to the question. It is clearly an answer which is in the nature of a debate. We have the interesting spectacle of the Minister debating Mr Strong, who is not here. I ask you, Mr President, to bring the Minister within the Standing Orders and ask him to shorten his answer.
—I think the Minister is extending his answer under standing order 100. I ask him to confine his remarks to the question.

—Very well, Mr President. The point is, of course, that with those other industries personal income tax is normally applied, and that is progressive, so that to some extent in agriculture and in very specialised and very highly talented personal services an element of the economic rent inherent in them is picked up. My final observation is that Mr Strong is quite clearly at variance with support for a resources rent tax or at least movement away from present production-based taxes, coming from some quite surprising sources. For example the Daily Telegraph of today reports Mount Isa Mines, one of Australia's major companies, as saying that taxes ought to be based on profits instead of on output. The Leader of the Queensland Liberal Party has advocated the same thing, as has the Leader of the Queensland Labor Party. I was informed by a journalist yesterday that another major Australian mining company, CRA Ltd, has expressed similar views, for publication. Mr Strong and all of those who oppose what the Government is proposing to do are clearly trying to swim against the tide of rationality and, I suggest, the tide of history.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It follows from the answer that he gave to Senator Zakharov with regard to the comments of Mr Paterson and industry policy. Has Mr Paterson communicated any views to the Government with regard to the attitude of his association to a shorter working week, as supported by the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and the effect that this would have on industry unit costs and on the competitive position of industry in the domestic market and the overseas market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to that question is no. Mr Paterson himself has not been in communication with me regarding that issue although--
—With the Government?

—Or the Government, as far as I know. But Mr Paterson, although not directly, and many other people involved in industry have communicated views about these matters to me and others over a period. I am quite aware of views within industry that the shorter working week will be detrimental to the interests of Australian manufacturers. I do not shrink from that or even from acceding to the validity of that proposition, because the fact remains that one of the issues which must be addressed in considering the competitiveness and viability of Australian industry-and there is a wide range of issues-is the whole question of on-wage costs, which have been assessed, reasonably independently I think, as being about 48 per cent; that is, for every dollar in wage increases there is a 48c additional impost in terms of on-wage costs.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, however, that that includes a number of things. I should have thought, for example, that a government in 1983, and a thoughtful government in 1982, would have had to be concerned about a wide range of issues involving the competitiveness, and so on, of Australian manufacturing industry. Those include the various aspects of on-wage costs to which I have referred; they include workers compensation payments; they include payroll tax; they include penalty rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Long service leave.

—They include a number of other aspects associated with long service leave and long annual leave. All those matters must be included for consideration as being impositions on industry. So must government charges, whether they be State or Federal government charges-they have risen enormously in the past two years-and the cost of investment. All those issues must be addressed. Mr Paterson has not made any comments to me about the 38-hour week. The Government's attitude to the 38-hour week has been expressed by me, for example, in relation to the textile, clothing and footwear area in terms of indicating dissatisfaction about the claims for a 38-hour week and requesting that any claims that are granted will be granted in the light of set-off arrangements in terms of productivity. That has been the official position that we have advanced in relation to that industry.

ANSWER.PARA: In conclusion, I remind Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle simply that about 75 per cent of Australian workers currently enjoy a 38-hour week or less, and that it is usually those who are on the 35-hour week who are most vociferous in opposing those who are seeking a 38-hour week. That is no answer to the question Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle asked me, I appreciate, but it is a very important factor to be taken into account.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. First, when will Telecom Australia be in a position to provide a full videotex service? Secondly, is there any danger that the gateway facility will intrude into the security or privacy of third party data base owners? Finally, will the Minister answer criticisms relating to Telecom's decision to use the British developed Prestel standard?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot answer that question in great detail at this stage, but I can make some comment about it. I understand that Telecom will be in a position to provide a full videotex service at least by the end of 1984. I was asked, secondly, whether the gateway facility to be provided by Telecom will intrude into the privacy of private or individual company data bases. I have every reason to suspect that it will not. I was also asked whether the Prestel standard which Telecom is currently pursuing is, in a sense, the appropriate one . I say, by way of preliminary comment in answer to this question, that if the previous Government three or four years ago had had the ideological understanding and the intestinal fortitude to provide Telecom with a videotex capacity at the time it was fully developed to the extent of being ready to go into service, many of the problems associated with the introduction of new telecommunications technology in Australia would have been avoided. At that time there was almost universal agreement that Telecom would provide the hardware of the service and that the data which would be transmitted over it would be provided by private enterprise. That agreement was welcomed by both private enterprise and Telecom. It was the best possible way of providing a service because it embraced the old engineers' hardware-software separation principle, which is of tremendous importance in the provision of public telecommunications services of this kind.

ANSWER.PARA: Because of the delays occasioned by the previous Government's position of three years ago, the whole approach of Telecom has had to be revamped, I think to the possible detriment of the service which Telecom will now be able to offer. I am not sure that that hardware-software separation will now be present to the extent to which it ought to be. A lot of criticism of the Prestel standard has been based on the fact that other systems such as Telidon can provide more colourful graphics and things of that kind. But I am unable to say at this stage whether Telecom will finally go ahead with that standard and whether at the end of 1984 it will have the capacity to make it compatible with the other videotex systems. I will seek further information from the Minister for Communications regarding the details of the honourable senator's question, but I think it is important to put it in that perspective.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lajovic Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I ask whether he can state the Government's reasons for a quite spectacular about turn in Australia's policy towards Israel expressed in the Australian Government's statement of 30 September, which was partially described by the Israeli Ministry of Foreign Affairs as follows:

QUESTION.PARA: Various components in the Australian statement must be considered as a deviation from the traditional approach, despite repeated reassurances brought to our attention.
I ask further: What were those repeated reassurances and who gave them?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that, following the recent announcement of certain modifications to our Middle East policy, the Israeli Foreign Ministry did express some regret at the statement and particularly at decisions regarding the Arab League and contacts with the Palestine Liberation Organisation. In response to that, the Australian Ambassador who dealt with the Israeli Foreign Minister in this respect emphasised that the Government's statement on the Middle East policy review was a balanced one based on a full understanding of the Middle East situation and of Israel's position in that area. That communication to the Israeli Government remains the Australian Government's position. Our statement reaffirmed Australia's fundamental commitment to the security of Israel and Israel's right to exist within secure and recognised boundaries. The Israeli statement itself, made by the Foreign Ministry, welcomed that reiteration of Australian friendship for Israel. There are bound to be some bumps from time to time in a relationship like this but there is no fundamental change at all in the character of our relationship with Israel and nothing of that kind should be read into the recent statement by the Australian Government.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Resources and Energy . Did the Minister see the report in the Age newspaper in which it was suggested that there might be some dispute about the sovereignty over the area in which the Jabiru 1A oil well is located and about which government would receive royalties from oil found in that area? Can the Minister advise the Senate whether the Jabiru well is affected by the currently outstanding border negotiations with Indonesia? Can the Minister assure the Senate that Jabiru is in Australian territory and that it is the Commonwealth Government which will receive any royalties which flow from this discovery?
—I raise a point of order, Mr President. That question was asked by me weeks ago and I received the assurances of Senator Walsh. A further question was asked on the payment of royalties.
—Order! There is no point of order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney is quite correct: The question was asked before by him. Nevertheless, a report did appear in the Age, I think, on Wednesday of last week-at least it was one day last week-and there appears to be some continuing misunderstanding about this matter. Mr President, as you have ruled, I think it is quite in order to clear up that misunderstanding again in the Senate. The Jabiru 1A well is approximately 200 kilometres away from the area in respect of which agreement on the border between Australia and Indonesia has not been reached. The Timor Gap, to which Senator Chaney referred, is a gap between two points on which agreement was reached some years ago, but the Jabiru well is some 200 kilometres away from that area and is not affected by the gap in the border on which common agreement has not yet been reached.

ANSWER.PARA: The second part of Senator Robertson's question referred to the constitutional or legislative status of the territory in which the Jabiru well and surrounding areas are located. The well is in the Ashmore and Cartier Islands area-an area in which drilling permits are administered by the Northern Territory, as drilling permits generally in off-shore areas are administered by territorial or State governments. But, in regard to all areas other than the Ashmore and Cartier Islands area, the provisions of the 1967 legislation, as amended in 1979 -the 1967 legislation being the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act-stipulate both the rate of royalty which will be applied and the distribution of that royalty between the Commonwealth and/or territorial governments. The Ashmore and Cartier Islands area is not subject to that distribution of royalties between the Commonwealth and a State or Territory and therefore royalty charges, if any, in that area would accrue entirely to the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Industry and Commerce aware of statements made recently by both the Australian Labor Party and Liberal Party leaders in Queensland that it is their respective parties' policy to divorce the control of retail petrol outlets from the oil companies in Australia? As each of these Queensland party leaders is promising the separation of retail outlets from the multinational oil companies but neither of them possesses the power to bring this about under State legislation, does this mean that the Federal Labor Party has turned another somersault and will now either legislate or support the Australian Democrats' Bill to separate petrol retailing from petrol wholesaling, or should Queenslanders, like the rest of us, regard the promises to petrol retailers as expendable immediately after the election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I would like to make it quite clear to Senator Jack Evans of Western Australia that no promises made by either the Leader of the Australian Labor Party in Queensland or particularly the Leader of the Liberal Party in Queensland are binding on the Federal Government.
—Are the promises binding on them?

—That is a matter for the honourable senator and the electors of Queensland to judge. I think they will probably judge that promises made by the Labor Party are more binding than those made by the Liberal Party in its present state of disarray. The Federal Government may well be accused, as all governments are, of turning somersaults on particular issues. We certainly do not do it at the behest of political parties in Queensland.

ANSWER.PARA: I indicated in this Senate not very long ago that the Federal Government has the matter of the divorcement of retail petroleum outlets from ownership and control by the oil majors under review. Proposed legislation is being discussed with a number of the parties involved, and it is anticipated that an announcement will be made fairly shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware of media reports of a military raid mounted yesterday by South Africa into Mozambique? What is the Government's reaction to this latest act of aggression by South Africa? Will the Government condemn outright this gross violation of the principles of international law and civilised behaviour?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government was appalled by Press reports of a statement by the South African Minister for Defence, General Malan, confirming that a South African task force yesterday mounted a military operation in Maputo in Mozambique. The operation was reportedly directed against offices said to house officials of the African National Congress, and several people are said to have been injured.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government unhesitatingly condemns the latest use by South Africa of its military forces to attack a sovereign neighbouring country. This attack, like similar forays by South African forces against South Africa's neighbours, will do nothing to resolve the continuing problem of instability and violence in southern Africa.

The Australian Government does not condone the use of violence, which is an unacceptable way either to effect political change in South Africa or to impede legitimate aspirations for change. As the Prime Minister made clear in Parliament in May following the tragic bomb explosion in Pretoria and the subsequent South African air force raid into Mozambique, it is likely that there will be continuing resort to acts of violence as long as the South African Government continues to refuse to negotiate a decent and equitable solution to the problems in that country.

May I say, finally, that the Government has made it abundantly clear that it is totally opposed and continues to be opposed to the inhuman apartheid system in South Africa. Until that system is dismantled and a form of government is introduced that recognises the aspirations of black South Africans, violence will, unfortunately, recur. The latest South African violation of Mozambique territory further demonstrates the disregard of the South African Government for accepted standards of international behaviour and its unwillingness to negotiate peaceful solutions to the problems of apartheid.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware that the public has been deceived as a result of the Budget undertaking that broadcast teletext decoding devices and similar equipment for the deaf would be exempt from sales tax? Does the Minister appreciate that 10 per cent of the Australian community has a hearing loss? Did the Government realise, when the decision was made to back down on the Budget promise and restrict this sales tax exemption to the estimated one per cent of the community that is regarded as profoundly deaf, that a majority of these people would be disadvantaged? It would be interesting also to know what criteria are laid down to define the term 'profoundly deaf'. In view of yet another broken promise and the fact that this represents a relatively small cost to revenue, will the Minister ask his colleague to review the decision in order to assist 10 per cent of Australians who have a significant hearing loss and would wish to take advantage of such devices?

—Senator Jessop's question referred to deception of the Australian people. The greatest deception of the Australian people on fiscal matters that has been perpetrated for many years, if not ever, was that perpetrated by the discredited former Treasurer, who in the run-up to the 1983 election said that the Government was facing a prospective Budget deficit in 1983-84 of $6 billion. On the day after the election it was revealed by the Secretary to the Treasury that the true figure was $9.6 billion. It was revealed also that the discredited former Treasurer was advised of that fact five days before the election, was asked whether the information should be released and answered: 'No, let us sit on it; let us keep the mugs in the dark; let us continue to deceive them'.

—I raise a point of order. I appreciate the diatribe that is being carried on by the Minister, and I could debate what he is saying right now . Mr President, I draw your attention to the fact that it bears no relationship to my question.
—I ask the Minister to relate his remarks to the question.

—I was, Mr President. The question referred to deception. I was just pointing out the greatest fiscal deception that has been perpetrated on the Australian people for many years, if not ever.
