INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 18 October 1983, from Senator Durack:

INTERJECT.PARA: Dear Mr President,
Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
'That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Hawke Government to establish a National Crimes Authority without delay.'
Yours sincerely
P. D. DURACK, QC
Senator for the State of Western Australia
Is the motion supported?
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Hawke Government to establish a National Crimes Authority without delay.

The Opposition has brought forward today, as a matter of real urgency, the problem of establishing a national crimes authority and the failure of the Hawke Government to act effectively in this regard to date. It has been brought forward for two major reasons: Firstly, this chamber should be most concerned about the urgent need for the establishment of a national crimes authority, a national body, to meet a national and pressing problem; and, secondly, because of the lamentable failure of the Hawke Goverment to meet this challenge. The shifts and starts, the delays and indecision of the Hawke Government in regard to this matter are, I believe, a matter of urgency and a matter for serious debate and consideration by the Senate.

Before I deal with that I want to deal with the first problem which is to establish the urgent need for a National Crimes Authority. I do not believe that there can be any real doubt, in the light of all the evidence over many years and in the light of the very authoritative findings which have been made by experts who have investigated this subject, that the existing law enforcement agencies in Australia, whether they be at a Federal or State level or whether they be in the form of a bureau of criminal intelligence or joint task forces, are an adequate response to the problem of organised crime. Of course, associated with the problem of organised crime is the degree of sophistication of that organisation, the expert advice that it can command and, most regrettably of all probably, the official corruption that seems to go hand in hand with the existence of organised crime. The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) recognised this when he spoke, as shadow Attorney-General, last December. He said:

The primary evidence of the need for some better investigative mechanism is the series of reports which have been made in recent years involving royal commissions, special company investigations and, occasionally, police task forces . . . those reports appear to amply demonstrate that existing law enforcement machinery is not very good at pinning down that organised crime and securing the convictions of those reasonably believed to be involved.

The Attorney-General said that, when in Opposition, in the second reading debate on the Bill for the establishment of a National Crimes Commission. I make it quite clear at the beginning of this debate this afternoon that the Opposition is not saying that the National Crimes Commission, which was the subject of its legislation when in Government, is the only model or the only form to be implemented to the actual letter or word of that Bill. But the Opposition has been prepared to let the Government have some time to look at the question for itself and decide whether it wants to amend that, bring forward some other model or whatever. What the Opposition is most concerned about is that long before now a national body should have been established to meet the national crisis. It has been described in those terms by experts. The phrase 'national crisis' is that of the Special Prosecutor, Mr Redlich, whose report was tabled in the Senate last week. The problem has been described by Mr Costigan as 'the cancer of organised crime'. It has reached such proportions in recent years that major discrepancies are appearing in the national accounts of this country which can be explained, because of their magnitude, only in the light of the underground economy represented by organised crime. It is, at least on all the evidence we have, one of the most serious threats that has ever confronted Australian society. It is depriving countless Australians, by the fraud perpetrated upon them, of their savings and investments and it is depriving the revenue of probably billions of dollars into the bargain.

Organised crime has been looked at over the years by many royal commissioners, going back perhaps to 1974 as a starting point with the appointment of Royal Commissioner, Mr Justice Moffitt in New South Wales. Royal commissioners were appointed during the period of the Fraser Government. Mr Justice Williams looked at the problem of drug trafficking throughout Australia during 1977, 1978 and 1979. Mr Justice Stewart was appointed to look into the ramifications of one of the major drug trafficking syndicates in this country, the Clark syndicate. His report, which was tabled a few months ago, is again of great importance and significance. There were also investigations by the Costigan Royal Commission on the activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and, of course, by the counsel assisting Mr Costigan, Mr Douglas Meagher. The papers Mr Meagher gave to the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science Conference earlier this year should, I think, be read along with the reports of Mr Costigan to get a full assessment of the magnitude and seriousness of this problem.

Finally, I mention again the report of the Special Prosecutor, Mr Redlich. I believe Mr Redlich was in a particularly favourable position to survey the field and to make an assessment because he was appointed last year following the tabling of the fourth Costigan report in this Parliament. He was appointed to procure specific evidence for which prosecutions could be launched. His report indicates the problems that he faced as a prosecutor dealing with the magnitude of the material that was available from the Costigan investigations. He was required to put the act together and to bring prosecutions. I believe in a number of pages in his report he has been able very succinctly to identify the problems. Whereas previous royal commissioners tended to emphasise one of the major problems as being the fragmented nature of law enforcement in Australia between the Federal and the State area, Mr Redlich has also emphasised the fragmented nature of it at the Federal level itself and between Federal law enforcement agencies. I think Mr Redlich's report, which we have before us and which repays the most ample study by members and senators, is one of the most important contributions which have been made to this debate.

The point is that all of these experts, from Mr Justice Moffitt to Mr Justice Williams, Mr Justice Stewart, Mr Costigan, Mr Meagher and now Mr Redlich, in addition to the reports of joint police task forces that have been set up as well in recent years to overcome the problem of fragmentation between Federal and State agencies, have come to the same conclusion. There is nobody better, nobody more experienced, in this area than these various gentlemen. They have all concluded, as I have said, that there is a national problem and that it cannot be solved with the existing law enforcement agencies as they are or even by upgrading their resources or bringing them together in bureaus of criminal intelligence or joint task forces or whatever method of co-operation is required . They have emphasised the fact that these solutions just do not and will not succeed, no matter how much good will exists and how many resources are given to them.

They have emphasised the magnitude of the problem at the national level. They have described it, as I have said, using such terms as crisis, cancer, menace, threats and so on. At that level, they say that there has to be a response which measures the problem. As I have said, that response that we as the Opposition see is the same as we saw clearly in government and as we acted to achieve in government: It should take the form of a national crimes authority. Whether it is in the form of the National Crimes Commission that we sought to establish by legislation that we introduced and passed through this Parliament, or whether it should be a somewhat different model is, I believe, a subject for very reasonable debate. In fact, reasonable debate has occurred amongst experts on that problem. There are differing views amongst experts on that problem. But what there is no difference about, what there is no doubt about, is that there has to be a response by the national government. There has to be an authority created which can take this problem by the throat and deal with it firmly, effectively and fearlessly. That is precisely where I believe this Government has failed and why this matter is brought forward for urgent debate today.
I quote Mr Redlich on this aspect of the matter because he says so definitely:

Now is the time to implement a scheme which will result in effective national law enforcement through co-operation and co-ordination. What is required is a national response to a national issue. A robust, independent national authority, unfettered by jurisdictional or bureaucratic constraints must be created.

But what I fear, from the way the Government has been proceeding in its seven months in office, is that we are now beginning to ask not when will there be a national crimes authority, but will there be a national crimes authority? The prospect is getting as doubtful as that.

This state of affairs contrasts with a number of statements which have been made over a period by the present Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). In opposition, in April 1982, when the Fraser Government first publicly floated the idea of a National Crimes Commission, Senator Gareth Evans said:

The Labor Party is willing to give serious and constructive consideration to proposals now being floated for a National Crimes Commission . . . A compelling case can be made that the traditional criminal investigation process, and occasional ad hoc Royal Commissions . . . are simply inadequate to deal with this new reality . . .

The next quotation from Senator Gareth Evans is very interesting from the point of view of the reasons that he and the Labor Caucus seem to be advancing for their inaction, delay and doubts. When the Bill for a National Crimes Commission was introduced in October last year, Senator Gareth Evans is reported as telling the Sydney Morning Herald:
It is unlikely that the ALP will oppose the Bill although we may have amendments on matters of detail.
That was a very good forecast, Senator, at the time. But this is the interesting part. He said:

The bill does appear to have met most of the concerns we have expressed about the Crimes Commission . . . The basic model seems to strike a reasonable balance between civil liberties and the interests of the community in effectively dealing with organised crime.

That was the level of the debate-I think a rational debate-that took place in this chamber on the subject. The Bill finally was passed, although the Labor Party opposed it at the third reading stage because it failed to get agreement to some important amendment.
In the recent election campaign, Senator Gareth Evans, presented the law and justice policy of the Government, which would:

Review the structure, functions and powers of the Crimes Commission. Labor supports the concept of a Crimes Commission with sufficient powers to continue and widen the vital investigative work commenced by the Costigan Commission . . .

So, on that promise, it looked as though the Government would act, when it was elected to government. It may have wanted to amend the body in some ways but basically it accepted the problem and would proceed with the concept. But it was not very long before difficulties were found. In April of this year, in a joint statement with the then Special Minister of State, Senator Gareth Evans said:
. . . the Government has decided that a further process of consultation and review is necessary before any final decision is taken as to the future of the National Crimes Commission.
Senator Gareth Evans is even quoted as telling the Canberra Times:
We are not committed to establishing anything. The whole issue is up for grabs.

TALK.START.PARA: —That sounds like him.

—It is all up for grabs. Yes, it is all very authentic. Anyway, he will tell us if he did not say that; but it sounds very true. In May this year, in answer to a question in the House of Representatives, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was very much more firm and definite about the subject when, in answer to a question by Mr Anthony, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: What we are doing is to ensure that by increasing the resources of the Costigan royal commission the work of the commission will be increased and improved and that, at the beginning of 1984, we will be in place, with the proclamation of the Act, for the National Crimes Commission--
this is the Prime Minister referring to the former Government's Act-
to take over, in the most effective way, the work of the royal commission.
What has happened to that firm assurance, that firm assertion, from the Prime Minister? It seems to be running into the sand, and sinking deeper and deeper into the sand.

I believe there have been a number of very disturbing moves in recent weeks which greatly qualify that situation. As recently as June of this year, Senator Gareth Evans was telling the Australian Institute of Political Science:
The Commonwealth Government supports the establishment of a National Crimes Commission and would like to see it operating from January . . .
In the next breath, he said:
The Government has now made up its mind, though no decision in this area can be regarded as absolutely irrevocable.

He must have known that there were great forces within the Labor Party which would resist this concept through hell and high water and that is now of course exactly what is happening. Indeed, at the National Crimes Commission Conference in this chamber at the end of July this year, the Prime Minister himself was starting to shilly shally about the very firm assurance that he had made. He stressed the fact that no final decisions had been taken in this area. I refer the Senate to the details of what he then said.

As I have said, it is quite clear that this whole proposal is now getting completely bogged down in the Caucus and is being frustrated at every turn by some very curious coalition of forces in that Caucus. I believe that the undertakings that have been made in the past by the Attorney-General and the firm assurance that has been given to this Parliament and to this country by the Prime Minister are now at real risk. It is not a question, as it seems to have been until now, of time; it is a question whether we will have a crimes commission in place at all. Certainly it does not appear that it can possibly be in place at the beginning of next year to take over from the Crimes Commission. Senator Gareth Evans has admitted that fact in answer to a question which he was asked last week, I think it was by Senator Jessop, when he made it clear that the date, 1 January next year, must be considered very much in doubt. I regret that Senator Evans adopted a superior attitude in answer to a question I asked him a couple of weeks ago. He told me to be patient and that all would be well in a week or so. That was a fortnight ago. He said that a full statement and a full model would be presented to this Parliament. Of course, they have not emerged. They will not and cannot emerge because he still has to do battle tonight with his Caucus committee on this subject. The so pathetic nature of this Government's response to this national problem was apparent when Senator Evans appeared on the Sunday program last Sunday. He was asked by Richard Farmer :
Do you expect that you will in fact end up with an authority?
Senator Evans's answer was:
I think we'll end up with something.

How pathetic is this response by the national Government to what is a national crisis. How pathetic it is in contrast to what the former Government, the Fraser Government, did in response to this problem. It not only formulated but passed through the Parliament legislation for a National Crimes Commission. Legislation was on the statute books ready to be proclaimed at the beginning of this year. The previous Government established the important Williams Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs, the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking. It also appointed Special Prosecutors Gyles and Redlich. That was a firm response to a national problem in a timely way. The performance of this Government, of course, is pathetic.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Senate of the terms of the matter of urgency we are debating today:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Hawke Government to establish a National Crimes Authority without delay.

There may well be a need for the Hawke Government to establish some kind of national crimes authority. I have said so myself on numerous occasions, as Senator Durack has not been slow to remind me. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Special Minister of State (Mr Beazley) and other Ministers have said so. The Federal parliamentary Labor Party said so last year when it supported the second reading, the vote on the question of principle though not the detail, of the Fraser Government's own National Crimes Commission Bill. But there is no need to establish such a body without delay, to use the terms of this matter of urgency. There is no need to establish it with the kind of urgency that is suggested by this matter of urgency. There are great and difficult issues of principle involved on which there are clear divisions of opinion within all the major parties, within the media and within the community at large. It would be absolutely senseless on a matter as sensitive as this, with implications as far reaching as this, to rush in without full and ample consideration of where we are going and without full consideration not only of the general principles involved but also a line by line consideration of the drafting detail. It is for this reason that the Hawke Government cannot and will not be pressured into making a hasty decision on the national crimes authority or crimes commission issue.

It is for this reason, the need not for haste but for care, that we do not agree that this matter is a matter of urgency. The Fraser Government's own Bill, about which Senator Durack waxed so lyrical a moment or two ago, did not observe these strictures. The Fraser Government finished, as a result, with egg all over its collective face, with the worst of all possible worlds. It finished with an Act that had, in the form in which it finally emerged, no support at all from the legal profession, from civil liberties organisations or from groups of that kind with that voice in the community. It finished, moreover, with an Act that had no support at all from the States whose co-operation, or at least the co- operation of the majority of them, is obviously crucial to the effectiveness of any such body. It had no support at all, in the event, from civil liberties organisations, from the legal profession or the Australian Labor Party because the Act which finally emerged was left with ill-defined functions, insufficiently limited jurisdiction, insufficiently defined and limited powers and insufficient safeguards.

The Act as it finally emerged, from the Fraser Government's consideration of it , had no support from the States because, despite the passionate rhetorical enthusiasm for the principles of federalism that we hear so often, particularly in this chamber, the Fraser Government failed utterly to go through the detailed consultative processes that are necessary to win the co-operation and the support of the States on a matter such as this. I simply presented the States with a unilateral fait accompli, demonstrating heavy-handed and total indifference to the legitimate concerns that the States had on that occasion. The ironies are abolutely delicious, but let them be enjoyed, particularly by Senator Durack, as he reflects upon the course of events for which he or the then Government was responsible.

The Hawke Government's approach, by contrast, has been very different. We did come into office with a commitment to review the Fraser Government's National Crimes Commission Act and to try to produce the kind of organisational structure and balance of functions, powers and safeguards that did meet all these various concerns. The last seven months have involved a continual process of working out that commitment, of debating and dealing with the issues and of trying to resolve all the many and various vexed issues that are involved in this matter. It may be that at the end of the day the Government will adopt the view that the problems here are just unresolvable and that there is no better or more acceptable way of monitoring, investigating and ultimately prosecuting organised and sophisticated crime than through relying on the police forces, the ad hoc royal commissions with their draconian inquisitorial powers and the desolatory assistance of the kind that might be able to be provided in the intelligence co- ordination area from the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence.

We have certainly been trying to develop a generally acceptable alternative approach. We have not been dragging our heels in the process. Let me demonstrate that by giving the Senate the chapter and verse. We have gone through at least four or five separate stages so far. The first two months were spent by me-I spent more time on this issue than any other single issue, including even the dam's case that was occupying me at the time-on exploring what could be done with the Fraser Government's model. Was it capable of redemption by minor amendment? Was it capable of organisational implementation in such a way that the co-operation and support of the States could in fact be secured? Hours were spent, days were spent and weeks were spent consulting with the chairman designate, Mr Justice Williams, and talking with all sorts of groups and interested bodies in an endeavour to answer those questions in the affirmative and to try to get a quick implementation of that Act in some appropriately amended form. But the conclusion we were forced to at the end of that roughly eight-week period was that there were basic problems in the structure. There needed to be a much more wide-ranging public debate involving all interested groups and parties before an acceptable result could be secured.

So the second stage of our approach to this matter-we spent most of May and June doing this-was preparing, publishing and distributing a Green Paper identifying systematically but succinctly all the issues and shaping up the questions that needed to be resolved before the final answer could be given and policy solutions stated. In particular, that Green Paper identified the basic choices as being between two quite fundamentally opposed approaches. They were set out as model A and model B respectively in that Green Paper. The third stage of our approach to this matter was the organisation and the holding of a national conference. The conference was held in this chamber on 28 July and 29 July. It attracted the participation of something like 100 people representing State governments, the police forces, the legal profession, civil liberties organisations and other appropriate community organisations. It was an outstandingly successful conference by any measure. It was not just an occasion for set piece rhetoric. I think this was generally acknowledged. But it did involve a very serious attempt to come to grips, in a very constructive way, with the problems that were identified in the Green Paper. At the conclusion of that conference, certain tentative lines of solution seemed to be emerging, which were expressed as best I could in my summing-up speech at the conclusion of that conference.

That, then, formed the foundation for the next stage of our approach. That fourth stage involved discussions with the States and the formulation of a basic working model identified over two or three pages in point form. That process took us the whole of August and most of September, involving several rounds of meetings with officials and Ministers, culminating in a major round-table conference of Ministers and officials in Melbourne on 19 September, at which general agreement was reached, subject in each case to consideration by the respective Cabinets and governing parties, on an approach which would be basically acceptable. That is, an approach that would involve an appropriate balance of powers and limitations on power, and would involve an appropriate input in both the composition and the procedures of the body for the States.

The current stage has been the shaping-up of that basic model into the form of detailed legislation. It is that which has been occupying the Government in the two or three weeks that have elapsed this month of October. Necessarily that has been a somewhat protracted process, as anyone who has ever been involved in the actual drafting of legislation will fully appreciate. One cannot foresee simply at the stage of drafting a basic model all the issues of detail which will arise and all the problems which would arise in relation to the language of it. Necessarily that is a process that cannot be resolved in a matter of days. It takes weeks; but it is occurring. Once the Parliamentary Labor Party, had taken the view that it wanted to see the whole of the Bill before endorsing the model in principle, which was a perfectly understandable view, we had to move to the stage-rather more quickly than I had envisaged-of drafting the actual legislation. It is that that we are dealing with now.

I hope that the outcome of this process, the consideraton of a draft Bill, will be a national crime authority model which does satisfy the concerns that people have. In that case we will proceed as a sixth and a seventh stage of the process , to a final round of consultation with the States in an endeavour to resolve such outstanding difficulties as one or more State may have in relation to this matter, and we will move to the stage of legislation.

Let me repeat what I have said before. It may be that at the end of the day-I hope that this will not be so-as a responsible governing party, we will decide that it is simply impossible to get the balance right; that it would not be wise to set up any kind of ongoing body; that it may be better to leave the situation to police forces and to ad hoc royal commissions. But if that is the result-I hope that it will not be-it will not have been for want of trying to get a solution. It will not have been without an enormous amount of energy and effort- something unknown to the previous occupant of my office-going into that particular process.

Let no one be in any doubt about the complexity and the difficulty of the issues that must be resolved here. It is not just a matter of being for or against some kind of crime authority or crime commission. If the debate is to be a sensible one-and it rarely has been in this chamber, and it has been even more rarely still in the media-it must be a matter of a debate about what kind of crime commission or crime authority one is talking about. The best and most succinct way in which I can demonstrate the complexity of those issues is simply to read into the record the list of questions set out at the end of the Green Paper as matters that needed to be resolved. There were three threshold questions for a start:
(1) Has organised crime developed in Australia to the extent that special, and perhaps novel, steps must be taken to combat it?
(2) Can the problems encountered by law enforcement bodies in dealing with organised crime be met by improvements to existing police forces and resources available to them?
(3) If a new body does need to be established in Australia to deal with organised crime, is there a feasible alternative to establishment of a standing Crimes Commission?

If one moved past those questions, one would face the very detailed questions as to what kind of body one is talking about. Under the heading of 'Functions', questions (4) and (5), though expressed in more technical terms, essentially boil down to this: How should the jurisdiction of such a body be defined? Should it be flexible and general in its terms, or should it be more narrowly limited to organised crime, and, if so, how does one define organised crime in such a way that makes some sense? The questions continue:
(6) Should the Commission's activities extend beyond the gathering and analysis of criminal intelligence to the assembling of evidence for the prosecution of offenders?
(7) Should the Commission itself be empowered to prosecute?
(8) Should the Commission be empowered to initiate particular inquiries independently of a ministerial reference?
(9) To what extent, if at all, should the Commission be charged with compiling statistics on crime?
(10) What responsibility should be given to the Commission for making law reform recommendations?
That is as to functions; then, as to powers:
(11) Should the excuse of self-incrimination be available to a witness called before the Commission in respect of
(a) oral evidence
(b) documentary evidence?
(12) Should the legislation enable the Commission to refer to the Federal Court a witness who fails to attend or refuses to answer these questions?
There are 25 questions in all, and I am demonstrating the complexity of the issues involved. The questions continue:

(13) Should the Crimes Commission be empowered to issue a warrant for the arrest of a person who fails to attend or where it has reason to believe that a witness is likely to flee to avoid attendance?
(14) Should the Crimes Commission be empowered to grant immunities to witnesses or should this be reserved for decision by the Attorney-General?
(15) Should the Crimes Commission be enabled to apply to a Court for issue of a search warrant?

If I may, Mr Acting Deputy President, I will incorporate in Hansard the remaining 10 questions. I do not want to bore the Senate. There is plenty more that I want to say, but I want to demonstrate for the record the difficulties and complexities of the issues here involved. I seek leave to incorporate the questions in Hansard.
Leave granted.

(17) Should the Crimes Commission itself be empowered to issue search warrants? (para. 7.30)

TALK.START.PARA: —The nub of this debate is the question of delay. Are we just fiddling while Rome burns? The answer to that is twofold. We are not just fiddling. We are going through an exhaustive process of consultation and debate, unresolved to date but necessarily exhaustive because of the nature, the complexity, the difficulty and the sensitivity of the issues involved. The other point that needs to be made is that Rome is not, in any event, burning. We have a de facto national crimes authority in operation right now with the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. It is not as if nothing is happening by way of the monitoring, the investigation, of organised crime. A great deal is happening and it is nonsensical for those on the Opposition benches to be pretending otherwise.

SPEECH.PARA: The Costigan Commission is investigating organised criminal activities on a very broad front. On last count-depending on how one defines them-it had between a dozen and 20 major separate investigations proceeding, all of them linked in some way to the original painters and dockers reference, but in some cases the link is pretty marginal. But clearly they are a wide-ranging set of investigations. The Costigan Commission, secondly, is producing reports to government, most recently last week, one volume of which was tabled but accompanied by massive and detailed evidence of very far reaching and alarming criminal fraud in one State. The Costigan Commission is generating prosecutions. Six people have already been charged in relation to the particular matter in respect of which the report was produced to government last week, and many others are being prosecuted as a result of the efforts of special prosecutors Gyles and Redlich, whose task has been to implement the recommendations and the prosecutorial implications of the Costigan Commission inquiry. The Costigan Commission is supplying further information to law enforcement and other agencies around the country, which has been and continues to be enormously helpful in tightening up the systems as they are operating and the procedures as they are applying, in removing loopholes and in avoiding future problems with the criminal law.

I am not suggesting and the Government has never suggested that there are not difficulties, however, with continuing on a completely open-ended basis with the present Costigan Royal Commission. That Commission has inappropriate and really ill-defined terms of reference for a body which is to operate as an across the board national crime authority. There are insufficiently precisely defined limits to its jurisdiction. Furthermore, that Commission is operating on the basis of unlimited royal commission powers which are draconian and possibly inappropriately so for the kind of body about which we are talking, with an ongoing charter.

There is an absence in the present Costigan Commission arrangements also for systematic input or involvement by the States and Territories. Clearly, that is an unsatisfactory basis for any ongoing exercise of this kind built around the Costigan Commission. But it is a going concern and it is doing more to expose and attack organised crime in this country-heroin importers, tax evaders, those involved in massive corporate frauds and the rest of the series of unhappy things that are happening in this area-than anything else that this country has seen before or is seeing operating through the police forces at the moment.

Apart from the Costigan inquiry, the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking is continuing in operation to deal specifically with the Nugan Hand matter. It is also continuing to play a major role in mopping up after the Terrance Clark investigation. There is a good deal of further information coming to light about that in respect of which Mr Justice Stewart, in co-operation with Mr Redlich, is doing something. Equally, police task forces are operating on a bilateral and multilateral basis in many areas of drug law enforcement in particular, but also in other areas of concern such as organised and sophisticated crime.

It may be that we need, as I began by saying, something better than that ad hoc array of responses which presently exist, but let it not be thought that the jungle is unmanned by hunters at the moment so long as the Costigan Commission and the Stewart Commission and that array of police task forces are in operation . There is no need for panic about the problem of organised crime in this country. It is a problem and it demands a Government response but it also demands a measured and considered response, not a rash and hasty one. The Government is giving it that treatment. We are proceeding with all deliberate speed and so long as we continue to do so there is simply no justification for an urgency motion being proposed in the terms it has been today by Senator Durack or being accepted by the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a pathetic contribution!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As my colleague said, what a pathetic speech! The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) at the beginning of this year came into the Parliament like a lion prepared to do all those things the previous Government had not done. Now, like a lamb, he lies down and tells us: 'There is no need for urgency, no need to panic and no need to worry. Of course, it may be that at the end of our investigations we may find that there is nothing to be done and that the whole problem cannot be solved'. Perhaps we should panic when we see that this matter is in the hands of a man who has obviously-I do not blame him entirely-been liquidated in small pieces by his Caucus and by his law committee. They are, of course, pulling to bits his small scheme for a crimes commission. I can understand his difficulty. But we in this country have to recognise, as he recognised in the past, that there is a real problem. It is a problem of urgency that has led to this motion today, which I will repeat:

SPEECH.PARA: That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Hawke Government to establish a National Crimes Authority without delay.

I will devote my speech to the question of the need for action without delay, action which has been deferred since the previous Government in December passed through both chambers, after considerable debate and amendments which satisfied some of the problems which some of us had, an Act which could have been brought into operation. Ten months after that legislation the Attorney has done nothing of achievement. No wonder he is now retreating from the chamber. It is, in fact, a position about which he must feel very ashamed because of his lack of action.

The Attorney has today given us 25 questions. Earlier in the afternoon, we had questions without notice. We then had 25 questions without answers, a new version of parliamentary proceedings. But the Attorney did have the courage to answer his extra question: 'Are we fiddling while Rome burns'? Surprise, surprise! INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator MISSEN

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, let us consider again this question of urgency that Senator Evans has said is no longer there. Let us look again- Senator Durack referred to this-at the question which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) answered in the House on 19 May 1983. Other parts of the answer by the Prime Minister show more resolution in the Government, even as short a time ago as May, than today. Mr Hawke, in answer to Mr Anthony in respect of his and the Government's actions in respect of a National Crimes Commission, said:

INTERJECT.PARA: I am in a position to inform the House of very concrete steps which the Government is taking, not to talk words but to translate into action the unqualified determination of this Government to ensure that everything that can possible be done is done to smach organised crime in this country.
Is that not magnificent?
Senator Sir John Carrick-When did he say that?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator MISSEN

TALK.START.PARA: —He said that on 19 May, a few months ago. He said that the Government would do everything it could to smash organised crime. Honourable senators will see that in those words there is a recognition that organised crime is important and serious and that it needs to be smashed in this country.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Sir John Carrick-And now there is no panic.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator MISSEN

TALK.START.PARA: —Apparently, there is no panic now. There can be a slight smashing over a period. In his answer, Mr Hawke continued:

INTERJECT.PARA: I can assure the House that, in the very short time we have been in government, those steps make the relative inaction of our predecessors pale into insignificance.

No doubt our colleagues felt very unhappy about those tremendous steps. What are the steps that have been taken? Those steps, presumably, are the discussions in the Labor Party slowly dissolving the idea of a National Crimes Commission. We then had another piece of pearly wisdom from the Prime Minister. In speaking of Commissioner Costigan, Mr Hawke said:

While ensuring that the resources available to Royal Commissioner Costigan-and I think the honourable member will appreciate the great work that has been done there-are increased, we are ensuring that, as a result of those increased resources, there will be a position in which there can be the most effective transition from the work of the Costigan royal commission to the work of the National Crimes Commission.

One would expect this. The limited power and limited operation of the Costigan Royal Commission is most unsatisfactory. Despite what Senator Evans has said, it is no good to say, 'Oh, Costigan is going ahead doing his work. That can go on. All is well.' What about the people who are working for Mr Costigan? What about the insecurity and inadequacy of not knowing whether that work is going to continue, whether it is to be brought to fruition or whether we are to come to the conclusion after a while that the whole operation is unresolvable. I think it is very unsatisfactory to find it left in that position. I do not think the people of Australia would want that to happen. It is clear that there is an enormous amount of organised crime in this country. We do not really need to argue that point today because reference has been made to the very many royal commissions and inquiries which have indicated its existence. We do not need to argue that point because on 7 December 1982 in the Senate debate on the National Crimes Commission Bill, Senator Evans, our Attorney-General, then spoke with strength. On page 3165 of the Hansard, he is reported as saying:
. . . the Opposition--
He was then in opposition-

comes down, on balance, on the side of the proposition that the case has been made out both as to the existence of very significant levels of organised crime in this country and for the need for better investigative enforcement machinery to deal with it.

The then Opposition found at that time, as Senator Durack pointed out in this debate today, that the model put up by the Fraser Government seemed to strike a reasonable balance between civil liberties and the interests of the community in dealing effectively with organised crime. I believed that at that time and I believe it now. I happen to disagree with many of my colleagues in some civil liberty organisations who, I think, have unnecessarily panicked and unnecessarily recognised that the balance has to be struck when one has a situation of organised crime in this country which so many of these commissions over so many years have revealed. Likewise, we have the words of Mr Costigan in his recent report. I refer to his Interim Report No. 5, volume 1. In it he reiterates what he said in previous reports about the need for a national crimes body. At page 18 of the report he says:

I have referred to this matter in some detail in Chapter Ten of Volume 2 of the Fourth Interim Report which was tabled in Parliament last year. I have no desire to change anything which appeared in that chapter. My conclusions are still valid. Those conclusions lead inevitably to the result that some permanent body should be established to make use of additional powers and sophisticated techniques of identifying and arresting this cancer.
That cancer, of course, is the cancer of crime throughout Australia. Mr Costigan on the next page went on to say:

The extent to which additional powers are given to such a permanent body must affect the view of Government and the community as to the point at which a balance should be struck between an effective desire to challenge the forces of organised crime and, on the other hand, the desire to restrict as little as possible the traditional liberties which citizens of this country have enjoyed.

Mr Costigan, for whom I have a great deal of respect, has conducted an investigation into so many of these things and has shown the effectiveness of exposing crime in quite a number of fields. We know that in this recent report he has not disclosed the detail, because that is in secret documents at the moment, but he has revealed that the investigation has shown there is a very serious further outbreak and that the revenue is being deprived of millions of dollars as a result of that. So there is, obviously, an ongoing need for this sort of investigation. Today we found that Senator Evans was uncertain as to how it will all turn out, with so many questions in his mind unresolved. It is obvious at this stage that we will not get from this Government an attack on organised crime. I repeat the words that Mr Redlich, who has the important position of Special Prosecutor, used at chapter 11.21 of his recent report:

Now is the time to implement a scheme which will result in effective national law enforcement through co-operation and co-ordination. What is required is a national response to a national issue. A robust, independent national Authority, unfettered by jurisdictional or bureaucratic constraints must be created.

Today we had the interesting spectacle of Senator Evans coming forward as the knight-errant of the States. He felt that somehow they were being disregarded and had not been considered in this matter. What we do know is the extent to which previous attempts to get co-operation between police forces of the States and other bodies has been unsuccessful. Of course organised crime can get across State boundaries with the greatest of ease and the greatest of success. What we have not been able to get at is the current operations of these various groups, including State police, who have an idea of 'turfdom'-I think that is the word. They are concerned with looking after their own turf, their own area. In some some cases one wonders why they are so concerned for the protection of their own turf or their own areas.
Senator Tate-Why do you think?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator MISSEN

TALK.START.PARA: —When I look across the border into New South Wales, to take an example--

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Sir John Carrick-Steady on; look kindly on us.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator MISSEN

TALK.START.PARA: —There are honest men in New South Wales-Senator Sir John Carrick and others are shining examples-but there is some very funny business going on in New South Wales. I have had personal experiences in the last year or two of trying to get documents out of the New South Wales Police and finding very curious things indeed. Let us note what was said by one man who was in office and who had experience of this. I refer to Fred Silvester, one of Australia's top criminal investigation officers who had to resign from his position as Director of the Australian Burerau of Criminal Intelligence. He could not get the co-operation of the State police. A report following Mr Silvester's resignation, in the Age of 2 June, had this to say:

INTERJECT.PARA: But he said the bureau, which he has headed since it was formed two years ago, was powerless against the organised crime interests which fostered corruption.

When it was set up in 1981, the bureau was regarded as the saviour of a system of fragmented intelligence sources and poor interstate co-operation. But two years later, Mr Silvester said, it was clear that the bureau had failed in its object of setting up a national intelligence network because of internal squabbling with the Federal police and the continued apathy of most States except Victoria.

He went on to say that the Bureau had never been effective and he was forced into resignation because of that. An even more disastrous position is revealed when one looks at an article by John de Meyrick appearing in the September journal of Law News. He points out the danger of the continuance of interstate crime, the dimensions of the effect it has on our own judicial system and the importance of having no interference with the integrity of the Bench. The article reports what Mr Douglas Meagher, QC said in a paper at the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science Conference. It states :
. . . the situation is so serious that it is only a matter of time before attempts are made to corrupt our judges.

At the same conference, the President of the New South Wales Court of Appeal, Mr Justice Moffatt, delivered a paper warning how oranised crime, as it becomes entrenched and sophisticated, ascends in its corruptive influence the ladder of authority and power.

'For example', he said, 'police officers in ascending levels, investigators, prosecutors, magistrates, judges, members of the executive government and members of the legislature in relation to the passage of legislation.

So the article goes on. It is a matter of urgency, a matter of danger to this community, that action is not taken to set up this authority. As one who has belonged for many years to many of the civil liberties organisations in this country, I believe that a number of them have overlooked and failed to recognise the balance which must be set in this country at this time. We have seen the extent of corruption in the United States and we have seen the growth here of organised crime to an alarming degree. We must recognise that this means some restriction on the desires and previous rights of persons to appear and not to produce documents.

Of course some of those measures are in the Bill already but it is not, as Senator Durack said, the details of the Bill that are significant; it is the fact that we must have a decision on these matters and put it into operation. At the moment the Australian Labor Party is busy with its left and right wings. I understand that its right wing in New South Wales wants some sort of authority because it will take the heat off the New South Wales Government. The left wing says that, because of civil liberties, it wants changes and so it is whittling down the Bill. We must see that this idea is not whittled down, that delay does not turn into complete inaction. The Government is to be condemned for its failure to act before now and this matter of urgency is right on point; it is what the Australian people need to protect their society from organised crime. I support this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) in rejecting the assertion by the Opposition that there is a need for the Hawke Government to establish a National Crimes Authority without delay, with the emphasis on the term 'without delay' in the context of an urgency motion. It has to be asked-I am rather distressed and troubled that Senator Alan Missen has taken the gung ho attitude he has taken on this matter-what is the imperative need for a hasty conclusion to the deliberations of the Government in relation to this matter? Why this haste? Will it achieve the sort of Australian society that we want to see emerge until the end of the century? Quite clearly the sort of Australian society we want is one that is not riddled by corruption, and the corruption in particular that is fostered by those engaging in criminal or illegal activities. That corruption can then reach into law enforcement agencies and political authorities and distort the better features of our Australian way of life. Surely we also want to see emerge an Australian society which equally is not ravaged by the undue intrusion of inquisitorial authorities and an extension of police powers that would put in jeopardy many of the freedoms which we do enjoy, if not alone then certainly amongst a smaller and smaller group of nations. As Mr Justice Kirby said in his address to the seminar on the National Crimes Commission conducted in this chamber, in regard to civil rights:

SPEECH.PARA: It is easier to diminish or abolish those rights than later to revive them.
He went on:

Many people in Australia, perhaps even most, are not fully aware of or even sympathetic to these limitations on the powers of officials. Because they do not themselves contemplate crime, they are prepared quite readily to abandon or modify basic principles which govern the relationship between authority and the individual. The defence of civil liberties has never been a particularly popular cause in Australia.

Senator Missen ought to know that. This whole enterprise requires some sort of vision of the sort of Australian society we want to emerge over the next decade or so. Therefore we have to strike the proper balance in ridding ourselves of organised crime, on the one hand, but, on the other hand, not imposing on ourselves extensions of inquisitorial powers, the defaming, smearing and destroying of characters and reputations without one iota of admissible evidence emerging from that process before commissions in a way which will found a prosecution. If there is anything we have learned from the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and the report of Special Prosecutor Redlich, it is that the activities of a commission in intelligence gathering do not necessarily lead to the accumulation of such evidence that can lead to a successful prosecution but in the meantime, of course, can destroy many Australians in the process.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the National Crimes Commission Act provides against that.

—I will come to the honourable senator's National Crimes Commission Bill very shortly. I remember that the Labor approach was well put in a statement by Senator Gareth Evans last October at the time Senator Durack's Bill was introduced. Senator Gareth Evans put down some 12 amendments which we were seeking to have the Government make to that Bill. We asked that the Government widen the grounds upon which the Commission could order hearings to be held in private. We sought to empower the commission to prohibit publication of the fact that a witness had appeared before it. We sought to remove the protection available under the law of defamation for reports of public hearings of the commission. We sought to make it a lawful excuse for refusal to answer questions that this would tend to incriminate one's spouse. We sought to reduce the terms of commissioners to two years, renewable once only, to ensure a regular turnover at the top and to reduce the prospects of the commission developing an unaccountable life of its own. One could go on and on. In addition, of course, Senator Durack's commission could act of its own volition and set off on its own hunts into the activities of various Australians whereas we at least are trying to devise some system of true political accountability which must apply.
—Some of those amendments were carried.
—But many of them were not. That is why at the third reading stage the Labor Party refused to endorse the proposal of the then Government.

SPEECH.PARA: All of those matters of concern are being dealt with in the proper forums of the Labor Party. As Chairman of the Caucus Legal and Administrative Committee, I say that I am certainly not going to be bluffed, blustered, pushed or steamrolled into dealing with these matters other than by a process which allows the fullest deliberation and consultation to try to get the balance right. Unless that happens, there will not be a national crimes authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —But Senator Evans said that the balance was right when the Bill was introduced last year.

—He did not say that when the Bill was introduced last year. We put forward certain amendments. Our support at the third reading stage was conditional upon the acceptance of those amendments but that was not forthcoming . We are trying to build in certain safeguards. The excuse of self-incrimination , of course, is a paramount one. We want hearings to be held in private if a public hearing would prejudice the subsequent fair trial of a person or the safety or reputation of a person. We are looking to provide legal and financial assistance to witnesses in appropriate cases, the authority to come within the jurisdiction of the Ombudsman, periodical judicial audits of the working of the authority, sunset clauses and the whole question of accountability which we believe it is essential to address and to get right.

SPEECH.PARA: But my real objection to this matter being brought forward by the Opposition today is that I believe it does a grave disservice to the Australian community in general in that it puts undue emphasis, I believe, on the creation of a national crimes authority to combat organised crime in Australia. We have this sense of urgency, this thinking that there must be no delay and that we must act immediately to set up this national crimes authority. The creation of this sense of hysteria and panic about the need to act this week rather than next week after considered deliberation has led to a gung ho attitude being built up among certain sectors of the community-a constituency which I believe will come back to haunt this chamber in future years.

Given the current range of matters which fall into the category of some organised criminal activity such as the distribution of marihuana and other matters-and I will come to that in a moment-this continual generating of hysteria within the community has led to the development of a very dangerous situation in which there is more and more demand by fearful people throughout Australia for more and more draconian penalties. We get petitions in this chamber asking for the death penalty for the pushers of heroin. Honourable senators opposite should not try to wash their hands of the sort of situation which, I believe, is being developed by the sort of encouragement which they are giving to this hysterical attitude. Once again, I think that Mr Justice Kirby's statement that these rights are easier to abolish than to revive needs to be kept in mind in the context of this debate. My first real objection is the conjuring up of fear and hysteria in the community on which honourable senators opposite are playing for political purposes to suit their own ends rather than seeing the clear need for the sort of balance which the Attorney has constantly put forward.

But my second point-and it is related to the first-is that, even if the national crimes authority were established tomorrow, it would constitute only a partial response to the problem of organised crime. As I say, the Opposition is putting too much weight on the establishment of this organisation. In fact, I think it is really putting considerable emphasis on the investigating, the gathering of evidence and the pursuing of inquiries by this authority and one hopes that in the end from all this some admissible evidence will be brought forward as a basis for successful prosecutions. The Opposition is putting a lot of emphasis on those aspects. But, of course, that action takes the heat off us as legislators and as the creators of government. In other words, we are responsible for making laws and administering departments and government authorities.

When one looks at the reports of various authorities over the last few years- and I will come in a moment to the very pertinent report tabled here last week of Special Prosecutor Redlich-one comes to the conclusion, I think, that really a lot of the blame for the growth of organised crime lies not in defective investigating techniques, though I do not excuse or doubt that some police forces have not been as vigilant or robust in these regards as they ought to have been, but fairly and squarely on the shoulders of legislators throughout Australia and those responsible for the administration of departments and agencies of government.

Every year since I have been in the Senate I have made speeches in various forms on the whole question of the circulation of marihuana in the community. I find that I have emphasised again and again in those speeches that by legislators throughout Australia failing to face up to the reality of the situation of the circulation of marihuana they have really forced hundreds of thousands of Australians, particularly young Australians, into a semi-criminal subculture where they are quite clearly the prey of those who want to lead them into the use of harder drugs for the greater profit of those criminal syndicates which are lying behind the distribution of large amounts of marihuana. We know that there is no pharmacologically proven progression from marihuana to heroin. On the other hand, it is probably true to say that all heroin users started with marihuana. The fact is that they get into that semi-criminal subculture where they are easy prey for those who want to manipulate and abuse them, make money out of them and then throw them onto the trash heap in such a socially destructive way. Perhaps these people then move on to harder drugs and as a result their young lives are destroyed. It is a peculiar legal system, a failure and inadequacy on the part of legislators, which allows that condition to flourish.

Senator Missen in his concluding remarks mentioned the growth of organised crime in the United States of America. Precisely, it grew in an era when prohibition was in full force. When alcohol was prohibited as a socially accepted legal drug in the United States organised crime flourished. We are doing exactly the same with marihuana. Until we as legislators face up to this problem, we are being hypocritical and, as I say, we are certainly putting too much weight on what we can expect of a national crimes authority.

I want to say something about the administration of departments. There is no doubt that we know that hundreds of millions of dollars were lost to the revenue of this country through the inadequate administration of the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office, particularly the Perth office, and various sections of the Australian Taxation Office and the Attorney-General's Department. Mr Redlich made very clear in his report-I could list three our four areas-that institutions, both private and public, are at fault in allowing themselves to be manipulated by those who wish to carry on illegal activities within our community. He indicted one of Australia's biggest banks which had sanctioned a system of using banking facilities for round robin accounts to avoid the payment of taxation. He pointed to the opening of false bank accounts and the high daily balances in branches. That was why it was connived at, aided and abetted by those banking institutions. In relation to public institutions, Mr Redlich referred to Telecom Australia. He said:
Telecom was consciously tolerating the use of its facilities for illegal purposes and denying police access to equipment to intercept the calls of SP operators to gather evidence.

Those are two examples of private and public institutions of great importance to our community allowing themselves to be manipulated by organised criminal activity. In relation to the whole question of the response of governments to organised crime, Mr Redlich said, amongst other things:
Poor administration, training and resources made Government departments and law enforcement bodies incapable of an adequate response to the ravishings of crime.
He also said:
The primary task of regulatory bodies was the administration of their acts rather than the investigation of crime.
He continued:
This approach results in an inadequate response to law enforcement needs.
He went on to speak of how those departments jealously guard their own territory . He said:
They frequently lack the basic resources to enable them to discharge their duties effectively and there is often a division of responsibility which works against efficiency.

What I am trying to build up is a picture which places the creation of a National Crimes Authority in its proper perspective. The fact is that this overhysterical approach of the Opposition not only, as I said, does not give due weight to the grave matters of the balance between civil liberties and the combating of crime, which is so important, but also could well distract us and the Australian community from our basic task as legislators and as creators of government to ensure that the laws which we make and the departments which we administer do not themselves become seminaries of crime. It is when we, as lawmakers and as administrators of departments, take our responsibilities seriously and responsibly that the National Crimes Authority, if it is to be created, with the proper safeguards, will play its part, which I am sure is what we would all wish to see.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of urgency exposes a further major failure of and a further major retreat by the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans) in what is an uninterrupted chapter of failures and retreats that mark the administration of his portfolio. He goes from failure to failure and from retreat to retreat. Today he laid out again the ground of his retreat from Moscow. Honourable senators heard his very prophetic words: 'It may be that the problems are unsolvable'. They were his words; not mine. They were his words after the holding of the seminar, after the Green Papers and after the months have gone by. I repeat his words: 'It may be impossible to get the balance right. Maybe we will have to rely on the present enforcement agencies and nothing else'. Where now is the clarity of the garrulous, if I may say so, Senator Evans in opposition? The man of urgency said: 'There is organised crime. It is very serious. It is urgent to deal with it. We must deal with it now. We in the Australian Labor Party have the instant solutions. They must be acted upon now'. Where now is that man?

SPEECH.PARA: What is the defence today? The defence is that there is no urgency at all about this matter. I use the words of the Government: 'There is no need to panic; Rome is not burning. There is not any urgency at all about this. Everything is all right. We are not certain now whether there ought to be a crimes commission'. How did this happen? It happened in a twinkling of an eye, from opposition to government benches. The man said that crime was rampant in Australia, that we had to act immediately regarding the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. In opposition he tore us to shreds. The garrulous man became the Gareth Evans. How did that happen? The man is now retreating; he is moving steadily backwards. He is preparing himself, against all the advice that he has had. As Senator Durack said, in October of last year Senator Evans saw the matter with some clarity. When speaking about the then Government's National Crimes Commission Bill, he said that it did appear to have met most of the concerns which the Labor Party had expressed about the crimes commission. He said that the basic model seemed to strike a reasonable balance between civil liberties and the interests of the community in effectively dealing with organised crime. That was not a bad statement in opposition.

Honourable senators will remember that Costigan painted a picture, a picture that is not urgent, now, of some 35 bloody murders. Most of them are unsolved. He painted a picture of a union which was then affiliated with the Labor Party. Costigan said that it was not a trade union at all; it was an organisation of criminals, organising as criminals, to assist criminality. There is no urgency at all about that now. There is no urgency at all about the fact that judges Moffitt, Woodward, Williams, Stewart and Costigan have said that crime in Australia has reached a state of great complexity, particularly in relation to drugs, that it is in the multibillion dollar sphere and is causing the deaths of and tremendous hardship to hundreds and hundreds of Australians. There is no urgency at all about that matter now. The Government believes that it can delay. When the Labor Party was in opposition it knew with certainty that there was urgency and it knew the solutions. I can only remind myself of what Aneurin Bevan said of another Minister at the time. 'He has an absolute genius for putting flamboyant labels on empty luggage'. My goodness, when I listened today to the speeches by Senator Evans and Senator Tate-who knows better, if I may say so-I could only say that those were flamboyant labels on empty luggage if ever there were such.

Senator Evans said that there may be other solutions to this problem; we do not know. A seminar was held to look at the matter. I think it would be very interesting to look at what was said at the seminar. I will give a summary of Senator Evans's interpretation of it. Incidentally, everybody knows that the series of royal commissions has said that the present law enforcement agencies are not good enough. In summing up the seminar, Senator Evans said that it was agreed that organised and sophisticated crime is a serious problem in Australia today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not now.

—It is not now; we can delay. Since July delay on this matter is a good thing. Never mind, that was what was said. Senator Evans stated that the seminar concluded that the police forces, in their present form, were under-resourced-that was his beautiful euphemism-meaning, in various people's terms, inadequate, inefficient, ineffective, undertrained and unskilled, without reflecting on the great body of decent policemen. As some of the commissions have exposed, there is some degree of corruption throughout the forces. They are inadequate, certainly, to do their job. Senator Evans said the seminar stated that co-ordination between law enforcement agencies was hopeless, that there was no great co-operation between police force and police force either State by State or Federal and State. He said that for a whole variety of reasons there was no willingness to co-operate. He said that ad hoc royal commissions were not the total answer and that there was a need for a more systematic form of national criminal intelligence collection. He then tried to crystallise what the majority view was. It was that there was strong support for a national intelligence gathering investigatory and co-ordinating authority. So there was the situation of this seminar summed up.

SPEECH.PARA: The seminar concluded that law enforcement agencies today are just not good enough, that, sadly, our police forces, for whatever reasons, are not equipped to meet the complexity of organised crime. We do not have the skills, the educational standards and the technology inside our police forces to deal with it. We do not have co-ordination between police forces to cope with the problem. The royal commissions have stated that so many of these matters are national ones and so many of them can be approached only in terms of national powers, passports, taxation, drugs, imports and exports-the whole fabric of Commonwealth powers as distinct from State powers. It was quite clear that this was a matter that had to be decided upon.

The situation is that nobody, royal commissions or seminars, has said that the existing investigatory bodies are good enough. I remember those beautiful words that Senator Evans used today in his retreat from Moscow. He said: 'Maybe the problems are unresolvable. It may be possible to get the balance right. Maybe we will have to stick with what we have got'. Can honourable senators imagine the retreat of that man? Napoleon would have declared himself an amateur when comparing himself with the retreat of that man from his position last year. He was the man who knew the answers to everything. Today he uses nothing but buzz words. Indeed, Gilbert and Sullivan must have had such a man in mind when they invented the Poo-Bah and wrote those lovely words of the Poo-Bah that it was merely a corroborative detail intended to give artistic verisimilitude to an otherwise bald and unconvincing narrative. Who could describe his speech today better than that? Words, words, words! In order to spin out the time he recited 25 questions with no answers. He had no answers after all this time. He did not have an answer to any of the questions at all. He knows that we, on this side of the chamber, always urged urgency on this matter. We, in fact, brought in legislation for the establishment of a crimes commission. We appointed a chairman. Senator Chipp, in speaking for the Australian Democrats, day after day , has moved for the urgent setting up of a body to inquire into organised crime. Nobody could be more forthright than Senator Chipp has been in drawing attention to what he regards as the urgency of this matter. It is a pity that the Democrats are not part of this debate today. That is the situation. What have we found? The urgency motion states:
The need for the Hawke Government to establish a National Crimes Authority without delay.

It is opposed on two grounds. Senator Evans said, first of all: 'Why worry about the delay? There is no urgency'. Secondly, he said: 'We may not need any national crimes authority at all; we may not be able to get one; maybe what we have got is all that we can possibly have'. I have never heard in this place such a pathetic retreat by any political party from the principles upon which it has stood or from the arguments which it has enunciated. I can only say that Senator Evans has been caught. His rhetoric has entrapped him in the jungle of his Caucus. His buzz words have been caught up with. He finds himself so trapped that he has to make this retreat. It is incredible that anybody could stand up here and say that at a time when, only days ago, it was revealed by the Australian Federal Police that there had been an invasion of the environment of a State Minister by an international crime boss. There had been an invasion into the surrounds and the environment of the State Minister yet to be fully identified in terms of its nature, and there is no urgency about that, even though, when he reported it, a police inquiry said that the information was inconclusive.

Is it good enough that the very fabric of our community today is being exposed, not by politicians, but by royal commissioners, as being threatened? Royal commissioners say that crime is so organised and so complex today that every part of the framework of our society is involved. Business, commerce, the unions , the judiciary, the politicians and the police forces are involved. Are we willing to have this Parliament, which after all is the basis from which democracy flows and the basis upon which our temporal values are formed, go on and have people pointing to us day after day and saying that there is evidence that politicians, the judiciary and the police are corrupt? No society can be safe or happy or go about content and with integrity if it believes that its police force is not safe. Is it only competition between police forces that forces them to be not willing to exchange information? What an ugly thing it would be if there were also an element of corruption stopping that from taking place.

In any case we know-let me pull this together-that royal commissions have said that the present framework of law enforcement is totally inadequate. We know that the present framework has failed to detect, much less to prosecute and secure a conviction. We know that the royal commissions have exposed. Of course we must look to civil liberties. When we look to the liberty of the individual, we must bear in mind John Stuart Mill as well; there is an overriding liberty- the liberty of the community. Day after day we sit here and allow the liberties, the freedoms and the integrity of the community to be shrunken because we are not willing to act because of some principle. Let us remember that this is not civil liberties we are talking about but a libertine behaviour. This is the law of the jungle and one that we must not tolerate.

There is no doubt in the world that there is an urgency about this matter. There is no doubt in the world that there is an urgency for major Federal intervention. It has been clearly established by the Opposition-sadly today it has been revealed to the public-that the Australian Labor Party has neither the desire for urgency nor, at this moment, the certainty that there is a need for any Federal intervention at all. The Attorney-General said: 'Maybe what we have today is what we will have to stick with'. That is simply not good enough. The Democrats have indicated that, the Opposition has indicated that and the public has indicated that. This has been one of the most abject retreats and failures that I have witnessed in this chamber.
