TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I take Senator Grimes's point. It is rather ironical that debate from the Opposition has just been closed off by someone who is reputed to have been the bag man for the former Liberal Party Premier of New South Wales.

—I raise a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. I should not have to rise on this point of order. Madam Acting Deputy President, I draw your attention to the Standing Orders and ask you to enforce them. You know that any reflection on any honourable senator is offensive. I reject that remark out of hand. I have never been a bag man in any sense at all for any political party. My integrity is as precious to me as the integrity of anybody sitting opposite. Let Senator Bolkus look to his own integrity.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I merely wish to support the point of order and draw your attention to standing order 418.

—I withdraw. In commencing the debate for the Opposition, Senator Durack, the Attorney-General in a government that was in office for over eight years, made the point that there is urgency for a national response to a national problem. This afternoon we have had from the Opposition the response that we saw from the former Government in the eight years it was in office. It was a totally inadequate response, full of rhetoric, full of superficialities, and did not address itself to the problem at heart. There are a number of matters that are undisputed in respect of organised crime in Australia. It is undisputed that there has been an explosion in recent years. It is undisputed that organised crime has existed in some States in Australia since the commencement of those States. That has been written about and evidenced in books and reports. Mr McCoy in a book called The History of Organised Crime in Australia showed that very well. But, as I said, it is undisputed that there has been a recent explosion in this area. It is also undisputed that organised crime has centred on a specific number of offences. Some have been going on for quite some time but the sophistication that has entered organised crime has now come about because of the use and abuse of financial systems, company structures and those sorts of avenues that are now available to sophisticated crooks. Traditionally we have had drug problems, the corruption of officials, prostitution, vice and illegal gambling, but now we have the other layer, the layer of sophistication-tax avoidance, currency violation and the like.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Tate, amongst others, mentioned that the problem with organised crime is that it is run from the top but that it is the individuals who are affected. Whether they are affected because they are denied the fruits of the Australian economy by the tax rorts or whether they are affected because they are the ones who are suffering because of drug abuse or the manipulation and abuse of them by crime figures using them as drug users and abusing them as prostitutes of one sex or the other, it is individuals who are being affected.

It is also undisputed, as I said earlier, that organised crime has developed in part over the last 30 or 40 years by sophisticated methods. The Cusack report into organised crime in Victoria in 1950 isolated the problem then as being one of the local family Mafia organisation. Cusack then predicted that unless measures were taken it would extend, and extend it has done. It has now reached greater dimensions and it is run by international crooks. Organisations within Australia have been organised with international links and they are flourishing because of that. We have seen Nugan Hand flourish. We have seen the Mr Asia organisation flourish and we have seen companies such as those involved in the poker machine industry also transcending State and national boundaries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who wrote the speech for you?

—Unlike Senator Walters I do not need to have mine typed out in large print. We have also seen organised crime interwoven with security organisations throughout the world. In fact it has extended its area of operation to unhealthy levels.
—You accept the urgency then, do you?

—I accept the urgency but I think the response is something greater than the honourable senator is proposing today. The basis of organised crime is linked very much with official corruption. If honourable senators look at the United States of America and at the responses that country has made, they will realise that the inception of crime authorities there may have helped to some extent, but organised crime continues. In Australia quite recently we set up a Narcotics Bureau. Now royal commission after royal commission finds that much of the activity that has gone on within Australia has been facilitated by the inactivity and corruption within that body.

SPEECH.PARA: It is rather curious that we have before us a motion moved by the Opposition as a matter of urgency, an Opposition which when in government was confronted with what is very much now at the core of organised crime-that is, as I mentioned earlier, sophisticated money channelling organisations. Year after year the previous Government received reports from its commissioners of taxation and reports going to the Crown Solicitor's Office to respond to tax avoidance-an integral part of organised crime, one that has been defined as such by Costigan, by Robert Redlich and others. But what was the previous Government's response? In one instance files were lost for over five years. I quote the now Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, Mr Howard, who is reported on page 887 of the House of Representatives Hansard of 25 August 1982 as saying that one of the reasons the two and half years elapsed before the Government acted against tax avoidance was:
there were people in . . . Government who wondered whether this piece of legislation was necessary-

It took the previous Government two and a half years. What we are talking about now is demanding an adequate and total response from a new Government after eight months. The Opposition that had eight years to do something about it now demands an answer within eight months. What was the former Government's response to that? Its response was to act on the Lynch razor cut proposals, to cut back the staff of the Taxation Office and to facilitate organised crime by facilitating the tax avoidance industry. That was its response then.

Need I say that the person who moved the motion this afternoon was himself fingered. In the document that was published very widely in September 1982 it was mentioned that tax avoidance schemes had proliferated over the last few years and that Senator Durack's office had not responded to them. Senator Durack 's Department had been conducting investigations for years without any efficient response to the particular problem.

Now we are faced with a new government, a government that is prepared to meet the problem and to meet it fully, but there are basic problems to be addressed in this respect. There are issues that the Opposition has neglected to attend to this afternoon. What offences are covered by organised crime? Let the people who for years have been travelling around Australia crying about States rights respond now. What are the offences that should be covered by a crimes authority? How should such an authority interrelate with the States? What sort of interests should the States have? Do they not recognise that there are constitutional barriers to an effective national response to this matter, or are they just prepared to forget the particular problem that rests in the Constitution that they hold so sacrosanct? Where is Senator Walters now that we are talking abut States rights?

There is another basic problem that we need address ourselves to. If we set up another body the problem that this Parliament must address itself to, the problem that this Government is addressing itself to, is that of accountability. How should such a body be accountable to this Parliament, to this Government and to the States? How and in what way should it be audited? Should it have sunset provisions and so on? Let me quote from Mr Justice Michael Kirby-much was made of this earlier by speakers of the Government-

TALK.START.PARA: —He is not always right.
—Neither is Senator Missen. Mr Justice Kirby made this point in his statement about the national crimes commission:

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst there are dangers that accountability to political representatives can be used to muzzle the effectiveness of a body such as a crimes commission, there are far greater dangers in allowing such a body to range widely over the landscape, with unusual powers within imprecisely defined functions, at the whim of those who constitute the body and who are not effectively accountable in a democratic way.

That is a concern that we should all have when we are addressing ourselves to the setting up of an authority. But the details, the particular problems, the accountability, the rights of the individual-I take the point from Senator Sir John Carrick that it is a very fine line between protecting individuals who are damaged by organised crime-are the sorts of problems that need to be addressed and Senator Gareth Evans has taken very much haste in addressing himself to those. I mentioned earlier the powers of the States. There is another matter, of course-that is how effective such a body will be. That is a problem that the Government must also face. The Senior Vice President of the Law Council of Australia, Mr Ian Temby, once again at the National Crimes Commission Conference , questioned how such a body could work. He addressed himself to the augmenting of powers of existing law enforcement agencies and went on to say:

The alternative is to erect a new edifice . . . that is likely to be expensive, the new structure might not serve the purpose for which it is designed, and it might even collapse and do a lot of damage.

Senator Tate mentioned-I quote only members on the Government side in respect of this because the input from the Opposition was rather inefficient-and I support his position-that there needs to be a total and comprehensive response to this problem. Of course, I can quite understand that this is a jovial matter for Senator Peter Baume and Senator Chaney. They had eight years to muse over it. Let me refer to the annual report of the Special Prosecutor. He acknowledges and claims that there is a need for an authority but he goes on to say that other areas need to be looked at, areas that could have been looked at over the last eight years, including the need for a uniform Evidence Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to get rid of the painters and dockers commission ?

—I refer Senator Walters to page 137 of the Special Prosecutor's report. It shows that there are problems with evidence that need to be addressed , that there are problems with the Crimes Act, with inconsistent procedures in different States. The Special Prosecutor suggests that there should be a federal offence to cover the problems that Senator Tate highlighted, those of federal facilities being used in State crimes. He suggested the codifying of criminal laws. He even raises the problem of evidence from foreign countries. He goes on to say that tax laws are in much need of reform. He lists on page 144 at least seven areas that need to be reformed and goes on the state that some of these areas incur a fine:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . of not less than $4.00 or more than $200.00.

They are problems that he highlights, problems that have been brought to the notice of government in the past but problems which, after eight years of government, the Opposition now comes in to tell us are a matter of urgency, even though it did not think so at the time. He goes on to refer to abridgment of time-this is a very vital matter which my colleague, the honourable member for Hawker, Mr Ralph Jacobi, has raised a number of times-and says that the Commissioner of Taxation has no effective powers to stop someone absconding. I read paragraph 16.39 to instance the particular problems he has. Mr Redlich says :

In one case I had to deal with involving millions of dollars of unpaid tax, the taxpayer on learning of the commencement of the investigation, but prior to the assessment being issued, had departed Australia and taken up residence overseas.
They are the sorts of problems that government needs to address itself to in the context of its deliberations on how to attack organised crime.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just what are you frightened about?

—I am not frightened about Senator Walters. She should be frightened about the vested interests that her colleagues have been protecting for eight years. Senator Walters has come to this chamber this afternoon with this concept, this edifice, and she proposes that that is the total answer to organised crime in this country. Let me say to her that the problem is much more than can be catered for by a national crimes authority. It is one that needs a total national response, as highlighted by Senator Durack. It is one that this Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) is prepared to embark upon with haste and, if one looks at the history of this matter over the last eight months or so , one will see that he has taken measure after measure towards some sort of resolution of the production of the body and it is one--
—You have lost your place, have you?
—I would not look to Senator Withers to find my place.
—I will put you in your place.

—In government, thank you. It is a matter to which the Attorney- General is addressing himself. Let me say in closing that there are problems involved with the National Crimes Commission. Problems were highlighted at the National Crimes Commission Conference which was held in this place earlier this year. They have been highlighted by more authoritative people than those mouths on the other side and I recommend those papers for the reading of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my contribution to this debate today I wish to review the debate that has taken place on this real matter of urgency, the need for the Hawke Government to establish a national crimes authority without delay, a national crimes authority to investigate organised crime, that which has been called by Costigan 'the cancer in our midst'. That there is organised crime should be now beyond dispute. It has been identified. We have had so many examples given to us by Mr Costigan. We have had the examples, as we have been reminded of today in Senator Durack's speech, given by Mr Costigan's assistant Meagher to the last Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science Conference. We now have the report of Special Prosecutor Redlich. We have previously had the reports of Williams, Stewart, Moffitt and many others. I would have thought that by now the question of whether there is serious organised crime within our midst would be well beyond dispute. That it is a national problem should also be beyond dispute. That it cannot be solved by existing agencies is a debate that we have been through before. It is not purely a question of reorganisation of existing police forces and other crime authorities. What there must be is a national authority. That was the state that we reached at the end of this debate last year. It can either be, as Senator Durack said, in the form of the previous Government's national authority or in some other form. We are not here today to put up the previous Government's authority as necessarily the perfect form. But it must be an authority which, as Senator Durack said, can act fearlessly and forcibly and it must be able to do so soon. The question before this Government is, however, no longer when there will be a crimes commission but, clearly, whether there will in fact be such a commission. We have seen in recent months a clear back pedalling. It is suprising, particularly to us, because it was not long ago, as the Senate has been reminded today, that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) himself was so supportive of it. I remind the Senate of his Press statement of 28 April when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party is willing to give serious and constructive consideration to proposals now being floated for a National Crimes Commission to investigate and monitor organised crime.
On 25 October, he said:
It is unlikely that the ALP will oppose the Bill . . .
In May his leader, Prime Minister Hawke, was even more firm in his resolve. I remind the Senate that he assured us that:
. . . at the beginning of 1984, we will be in place, with the proclamation of the Act, for the National Crimes Commission to take over, in the most effective way, the work of the royal commission.

He assured the House of Representatives on 19 May 1983, that at the beginning of 1984 the Act will be in place, a crimes commission will be in place. We have seen since then a clear back pedalling so that now those assurances are at real risk. That leads me to the incredible statement of the Attorney-General in June when he said:
The Government has now made up its mind--
It had made up its mind to support the establishment of the National Crimes Commission-
Though no decision in this area can be regarded as absolutely irrevocable.

So it has made up its mind, but it is entitled to change its mind again. I suggest that that is an astonishing statement, but not as astonishing as the statement made last Sunday morning on the Sunday television program. When asked by Farmer:
Do you expect that you will in fact end up with an authority?
His answer was:
I think we will end up with something.

What was Senator Evans's argument today? He said that there may be reasons for the establishment of a National Crimes Commission. He conceded that much. But he principally said that there was no urgency. That is something that I would have thought was totally in conflict with the numerous commission reports that have been put before us. He said that there is plenty of time for debate. In fact, there has been plenty of time for debate. The debate led last year to an Act. We have had the National Crimes Commission Conference that he reminded us of, we have had numerous reports, commissions, other debates and the Green Paper which he also reminded us of. He referred to the questions in the Green Paper which he said must now be answered. But I remind the Senate that in his final statement to the National Crimes Commission Conference he, in fact, answered most of those questions. I draw the attention of the Senate to page 270 of the transcript of the proceedings, which I do not have time to read in detail. But-to give the Senate an example-he said:

. . . I discern no disagreement about at least the following propositions: Firstly, organised and sophisticated crime is a serious problem in Australia today. Secondly, the police are under-resourced in dealing with the problem. Thirdly, co-ordinated mechanisms, such as they are, are capable of improvement in dealing with that problem.

So the questions have been asked and answered. Then he said: 'Are we fiddling while Rome burns?' It is not for us to say what fiddling takes place in Caucus sub-committees. But clearly what fiddling is taking place is not leading to a commission being set up. Senator Missen today proved to the Senate that the urgency for the establishment of a crimes commission was beyond dispute. I think it is significant that Senator Missen, who is known to be one of the chief civil libertarians of this Parliament, is so convinced of the need to set up a crimes commission. Senator Tate also, astonishingly, saw no need for urgency. He said that undue intrusion by inquisitorial and police powers is something that we must guard against. We all accept that. That is the debate we went through last year, the debate that was hammered out, the debate that in effect was answered again by Senator Evans when on 25 October last year he said:

The bill does appear to have met most of the concerns that we have expressed about the Crimes Commission concern. The basic model seems to strike a reasonable balance between civil liberties and the interests of the community in effectively dealing with organised crime.

So he acknowledges there that that debate has passed and a reasonable balance has been found. Yet he called the Opposition hysterical. I just cannot understand that. To regard organised crime in Australia and the extent to which it has reached as hysterical is an astonishing rationalisation.

I am severely limited in time and though I should like to review the eloquent contribution of Senator Sir John Carrick, I cannot. Senator Bolkus surprised me, I must acknowledge, because he accepted the existence of organised crime. In the first half of his speech he also acknowledged, in conflict with Senator Gareth Evans and Senator Tate, the urgency of dealing with it. But then, towards the end of his speech, he seemed to depart from the question of urgency.

It is clearly now decision time. In the last week or so we have had further evidence put to us by another Costigan report and the first annual report of the Special Prosecutor, Mr Redlich. The latter was a most disturbing, disquieting report, particularly in its criticism of the Reserve Bank of Australia, Telecom Australia, the Australian Federal Police and the Australian Taxation Office which were all singled out for their failure to check serious crime occurring under their jurisdiction. He said in summary:

The opportunity is now present for the Commonwealth Government to achieve a major breakthrough in the co-ordination of the investigation of crime in Australia. A national authority to investigate crime should be an immediate priority.
I remind Senator Bolkus who mentioned this report that Mr Redlich said that it should be an immediate priority. Mr Redlich continued:

The public expects such an authority. Some State and Federal law enforcement agencies support it. Other law enforcement agencies are resigned to it. The state of crime in Australia and the disorganised response thereto cries out for it.

What is the problem with the Australian Labor Party in this matter? Why is it unable to make a decision now that it is in Government and has to face the problem of making decisions? I think it was delightfully summarised-I will conclude on this point-in an article of 5 August this year by Claude Forell in the Age when, in the last paragraph, he said:
Compromise and consensus may be trendy political virtues but they won't cut much ice with crime and vice.
I move:
That the question be now put.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.

We insist that the percentage link between the Government-school standard costs and per capita grants to non-Government schools must be retained.
I seek leave to incorporate this pastoral letter in Hansard.

The letter read as follows-
PASTORAL LETTER FROM THE BISHOPS OF VICTORIA ON EDUCATION MATTERS

Dear Catholic People, Nearly twenty years ago the Australian Government took the first small steps to remove the injustice under which parents who wanted a Christian education for their children had laboured since before Federation. In 1967 the Victorian Government introduced a basic grant for children at all independent schools. Since that time there has been progress, especially at the Federal level, towards justice for all Australian school children.
However recent developments, both locally and nationally, threaten to reverse this progress.
It is for this reason that we, the Catholic Bishops of Victoria, believe it necessary to reaffirm our basic principles and to voice our grave concerns.

We are concerned about three things especially. First, the Australian Government is abolishing the percentage link between the cost of educating a child in a Government school and the size of per capita grants to independent schools. Second the Australian Government is backing away from the principle of a fair basic grant to every child. Third, the Victorian Government has already accepted the first two parts of the extraordinary first Report of the new State Board of Education and is considering the acceptance of the third part, which is so hostile towards independent schools. These developments threaten giant steps back into the unhappy past.
Right of Parents

All children have the right to education. So too all parents, not only Catholic parents, ''have the prior right to choose the kind of education that shall be given to their children''. These words are taken from the Universal Declaration of Human Rights adopted by the United Nations General Assembly in 1948. Australia is a signatory to this Declaration. Such rights are also asserted in the European Convention of Human rights.

The right of parents to freedom in choosing to have their children educated according to their religious and philosophical convictions is not merely an empty freedom to bear the cost of sending their children to private or parochial schools. It is one which involves a corresponding duty on the part of political authorities to furnish parents with the financial assistance necessary to enable them to exercise this human right. No Government committed to parents' right to choose can set up one system of education and insist that everybody should use that system or pay for their chosen alternative. This effectively destroys the rights of parents to choose and is an act of injustice towards those parents.

We categorically reject the notion that Government money ear-marked for education belongs by right only to Government schools and that anything given to non-Government schools is by way of concession or hand-out.

The right of choice is not one on which Catholic parents are selfishly insisting. They seek it with all confidence in the fairness and goodwill of their fellow Australians and with all willingness to pay their share of the total expense of educating all Australian children. They do not see themselves in competition with the Government system, but regard justice in this matter as a victory for education in all its forms.

At State level, funds granted this year to a child in an independent school approximate 23% of what is granted to a child in a Government school. At Federal level, the grant is between 20% and 40% depending on how needy a school is judged to be.
Acceptable Principles

We insist that the percentage link between the Government-school standard costs and per capita grants to non-Government schools must be retained. unless this is done, there is clear discrimination between parents who exercise their right to a choice of a non-Government school and parents who-no matter how rich they may be-have their choice of a Government school totally supported by taxpayers' money. We repeat that freedom of choice is not genuine if people are discriminated against unless they choose one of the available options.

We understand that those who seek special facilities over and above the basic needs of schools may be expected to pay for them. We would support a system which recognises need as a factor in funding, provided that such a system builds on the provision of a basic grant for all children and that the basic grant is fair and realistic. We wish to see the parents of children in independent schools treated as fairly as those with children in Government schools. Any other system is basically unjust.
New Government Guidelines

Recently the Australian and Victorian Governments appear to have moved against the rights of parents by severely reducing the basic grant to some non- Government school pupils. In both cases, these are only interim measures. There is the possibility that further cuts, or even the elimination of the basic grant , might follow. The fact that most of the pupils affected are not at Catholic schools does not lessen our concern. The issue is one of principle. We support the right of all parents to a share of the taxpayers' money for the education of their children, whether they choose Government schools, Catholic schools or other independent schools. The basic grant must not become a mere token, or be completely abolished.

It is unfortunate that some money appears to be earmarked for 'needy' Catholic schools at the expense of other Church schools. This is not the whole story. If the recommendations of the controversial Report of the State Board of Education were to be accepted by the Victorian Government, then less than half of the money available for reallocation would be available for 'needy' schools.

The whole tone and content of the Report of the State Board was disturbing. The Report was hostile in tone and divisive in trend. There was no evidence of any attempt at effective consultation, much less any evidence of consensus.

In the Federal sphere, the last Budget increased the money available to education. This is to be applauded. However, while there was an increase of 5.6% in the money for Government schools, the increase for independent schools was only 1.5%. But what is more important, and alarming, is that the Commonwealth Schools Commission guidelines have broken the automatic percentage link between Government school standard costs and the per capita grants to non-Government schools. This can be seen as the prelude to further assaults on the basic grant and an attempt to foster division among independent schools. The Catholic community feels strongly about the principle involved in the present substantial cuts to the basic grant.
Cooperation with Governments

The freedom of Catholic schools and their religious and moral character have always been central concerns of the Catholic community. We are most disturbed therefore by the Schools Commission's proposal that funding for schools in ' established' areas will not be recommended unless it can be shown that there will be no significant impact on enrolments of other schools in those areas. We have tried and we will continue to try to coordinate our plans and to cooperate with Government school authorities. But we fail to see why so much of the blame for earlier planning errors should be attributed to independent school communities.

In the wake of the Radford College Report we were relieved to hear the Federal Minister for Education state unequivocally that ''this Government has no intention of pursuing a policy of integrating non-Government schools with Government schools''. In the light of the State Board of Education's recommendations on financial accountability, curriculum, enrolments and governance in non-Government schools, we will welcome a similar assurance from the Premier of Victoria that our freedom will not be curtailed in these areas. We support cooperation, the sharing of resources where appropriate and the requirement of accountability for the use of taxpayers money in all Victorian schools, Government and non-Government. We are determined to protect not only our rights, but the precious freedom and rights of all educational agencies in a democracy.
Catholic School Achievements

The Catholic community has every reason to be proud of the achievements of its schools. Over the last fifty years Catholic teachers, both religious and lay, have enabled huge numbers of their students to achieve a degree of social mobility which has not been bettered anywhere in the Western world. The vitality of ethnic communities in Catholic schools is special proof that this work is continuing.
Message to Parents

We assure you parents who have entrusted your children to the care of Catholic schools that the bishops, priests, religious and lay teachers associated with these schools see these children as a sacred trust. We the Bishops of Victoria, urge you to continue to support the priests, the religious and the lay teachers in their work with school children, especially in circumstances where religious and educational development is difficult. We urge you to take up once again the task of explaining the Catholic position to the general public. We urge you to continue to protect the position of Catholic schools in the mainstream of Australian life.

One great strength of Catholic schools is the extent of parent involvement. Parents are not just behind the schools with money and moral support. They contribute an enormous number of hours of unpaid work and expert advice.
Confidence in Students

We want to say a special word to you young Catholics who are the students in our schools. To you we say: We Bishops are proud of you. You fill us with optimism. You respond so generously to the sacrifices made by your parents, to the degree of funding provided by our Governments, and to the lives of Christian professionalism dedicated to you by your teachers. Enjoy all this, get all you can out of it, in Faith and in study, in games and in friendships. And we would also say to you. Never let anyone make you regard Government schools as the enemies of our schools or Government school children as your antagonists. They are your fellow Australian adults of the next generation. We trust you then to work with them for an Australia even better than it is today.
Our Common Task

We conclude by commending these concerns to the Catholic community for consideration and action. We have restated and reaffirmed our principles. We cannot remain silent while the improved ecumenical relationships between the Churches are damaged or when different sections of the community are set against one another.

Our common task as citizens is to improve the educational opportunities of all young Australians. Much needs to be done, which will require those qualities of the spirit which have sustained Australians in the past. A satisfactory outcome of the educational enterprise cannot be achieved by money alone, nor can it be achieved by trampling on the rights and freedom of people in a democratic society. That is one of the great lessons of history. May we all be wise enough to heed it.
T. F. Little
Ronald A. Mulkearms
John A. Kelly
Eric Perkins
Joseph P. O'Connell
Noel D. Daly
Eric D'Arcy
9th October 1983

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, it demonstrates extreme graciousness when the result of granting an adjournment is to guarantee the defeat of the Government's position. Let me briefly state why: While still leaving much of the Bill intact and certainly still leaving it as a proposal worth supporting at a referendum, it is the case that Senator Hill's amendment would remove from the scope of the Bill one very important aspect of the High Court's proposed advisory jurisdiction, namely, the right of the Government to obtain a ruling on the validity of the provisions of a Bill after it has been introduced but before it has been debated in Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The rationale for including this type of problem in the matters which may be covered by an advisory jurisdiction basically come down to this: There are occasions when it would be desirable to obtain an advisory opinion before legislation is enacted because of the large savings of parliamentary time that would be involved. Honourable senators will not need be told that parliamentary time, particularly in the Senate, is a very scarce resource. It would be arguably quite absurd for a major piece of legislation, such as the National Companies Act, to be debated clause by clause over a very lengthy period if the subsequent outcome of a legal challenge would be simply to cut that legislation off at its knees because of the shakiness of its constitutional foundations. The other example that should appeal to honourable senators is something that might arise in the context of the family law legislation and the Commonwealth's powers with respect to marriage and matrimonial causes, the scope of which is still quite uncertain.

An ability to obtain an advisory opinion at an early stage would not only expedite the parliamentary consideration of these things and not waste time on things that had no chance of ultimate survival but also would, of course, help to remove uncertainty in the community at large which may well prevail for the duration of such a debate on complex legislation. That is something which is particularly, I believe, to be avoided in the context of commercial legislation in the areas of companies, securities and other matters of this kind. The whole confidence of the business community is crucial to its effectiveness and being neurotic about regulatory legislation of some kind or another, particularly in an area fundamental to its operation, can have untoward economic consequences.

I would add further that there is nothing particularly unusual about this proposal in the form in which it has been advanced by the Government. Certainly, in Canada the advisory jurisdiction, although not couched specifically in the language of proposed enactments, is very wide and extends expressly to private Bills and to what are stated to be important questions of law or fact involving the interpretation of the British North America Act; that is, the Canadian Constitution as it then was. It would appear that this kind of jurisdiction is available in that country and its existence does not seem to have alarmed anyone particularly unduly.

Finally, I say this in relation to the historical background of this proposal: The Judicature Committee of the Australian Constitutional Convention recommended in 1977 that the jurisdiction should extend to proposed enactments. Although it did not spell out the reasons for this recommendation, it is clear that it was based largely on the view that it ought to be possible to obtain an advisory opinion-and I quote from page 21 of the 1977 report embodied in the proceedings of the Perth Convention of 1978-'before the lengthy and time consuming process of passage through Parliament has been completed and perhaps wasted'. The Adelaide Convention in April this year approved a resolution on which this Bill is based which again covers proposed enactments. An amendment moved by Mr Spender, rather along the lines of that of Senator Hill today, to remove that right and to seek advisory opinions being limited to actual enactments was in fact defeated by 38 votes to 48 votes, the ultimate resolution in favour of advisory opinions being passed by a larger margin.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that the amendment proposed by Senator Hill will also be helpful in limiting the innovation of this proposal. I think that a useful area-admittedly an experimental area-will still be available. But, undoubtedly, to go to the extent to which this Bill originally proposed and for which the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) still argues, will likely create greater concern and opposition to the proposal when it goes to the people. I think the proposal that Bills will be able to be submitted to the High Court for such an opinion without necessarily having the support of the Parliament confuses to quite an extent the difference between the legislative and judicial role, and it is that confusion of roles which, of course, is at the heart of the concern at the whole proposal for an advisory jurisdiction. I think in all the circumstances it would be wise for the proposal to be submitted in the more limited form which would result from the adoption of Senator Hill's amendment. I think that a useful area would still be left for advisory jurisdiction. It would give the High Court and the government of the day the opportunity to test the proposal on a more limited basis. I think that in the long run it would be better to put the proposal to the test in that way. We could see how it worked before the more adventurous proposal of Senator Gareth Evans's which is contained in the Bill was pursued. For all those reasons, the Opposition has decided that it will support Senator Hill's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting Senator Hill's fresh amendment. We indicated last week that although the previous amendment had merit we required some time to study it. In the event, the amendment has been tidied up and certainly the Government can see that it will fit in with the overall Bill. I must admit that our main worry last week was that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) had not had the opportunity to vet the amendment. We wanted the amendment to hold up and not run foul of other parts of the legislation. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose the greater part of the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill, but we will be opposing sub-clauses 30 (2) and 30 (3) at the Committee stage. It is expected that the matter will probably be debated in its final form tomorrow. So, at this stage, I address my remarks to one or two other matters included in the legislation. Firstly, I note that the increase in the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill this year is something like 19.3 per cent over the total allocations in the 1982-83 financial year. That represents an increase in money terms of some $2.7 billion. If we examine the components of that increase, it breaks down very roughly into three items. The first billion dollars is due to the increase in the unemployment benefit this year. The second billion dollars is made up of the cost of index- ation of various pensions and benefits. The remaining $700m relates more particularly to items associated with the extra payments this financial year and to one or two increases in benefits which arise from this piece of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the point has to be made that, significantly, the increase which, as I have mentioned, is of the order of 19.3 per cent this year, arises chiefly from two items-indexation and an increase in the unemployment benefit. It is pretty easy to recognise where the bulk of the increase in welfare expenditure in the Federal Government's Budget comes from. The two factors that influence this increase this year, and have done so for some years, are inflation, which is the reason for the indexation of pensions and benefits, and the very significant recession that we have in the Australian economy that is causing such high levels of unemployment. The point I make is that the fundamental issues that confronted the Fraser Government during its seven years in office in dealing with the question of the so-called blow-out in expenditure and welfare are exactly the same items and issues that confront us at the present time; that is, the main causes for our problems are the recession and, of course, inflation. It remains to be seen how the Hawke Government will deal with these matters. So far it has shown absolutely no indication of how it will deal with either of these questions to the satisfaction of the Australian people. In some sense, the increases that it signifies in this Budget for welfare expenditure are admissions of that defeat.

Quite apart from those aspects, one or two items are included in the Bill which are, I think, of great benefit to the community. There has been a recognition of those who live in remote areas of Australia. We applaud the Government for introducing the remote area allowance which will add another $7 a week to a person who receives a pension, a benefit or a sheltered employment or rehabilitation allowance and who lives in the tax Zone A as it is defined. That matter was drawn to my attention when travelling through the remote areas of Australia and particularly through the Northern Territory recently. I believe that is a very worthwhile measure in that it recognises the extra costs that arise from residing in those difficult areas of Australia.

The second item for which we give due credit to the Government is the introduction of the spouse career's rebate which is more or less a mirror of the wife's pension which is available to wives placed in the situation of caring for disabled spouses. One point which concerns me in relation to that is the apparent lack of ability on the part of the Government to estimate what might be the take-up rate in this area. In fact, in an answer to a question on notice that I received last week, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) said that his best guess at the number that would take advantage of this new benefit would be roughly 2,000 men. I hope that the Government will make every effort to advertise this benefit to the people in the community so that there is a very significant understanding about its availability. It is also a little worrying that no attempt has been made accurately to estimate the take-up other than that which I have mentioned.

The third item which is of significance and is, I think, a very important initiative is the open employment incentive bonus which will be payable to people who complete six months sheltered employment and who complete 12 months open employment thereafter. That person will receive a payment of $500. The Government has indicated that there is a potential demand from a little over 9, 000 people in that category. I am not sure what the take-up rate will be and I am not certain that the Government knows either, but it is another point that needs to be brought home as a result of the decision. The people should be made aware of this entitlement and we should make sure that they take up this very significant advantage.

There have been several different changes, too, in respect of the rates of unemployment benefit. There has been an increase of $4.95 a week in the unemployment benefit for single persons over 18 years of age. Indexation was introduced this year on the over-18 single unemployment benefit starting from 1 May next year. One wonders why it was not introduced a little earlier than that. There was an increase of $5 a week for single unemployed people aged between 16 and 17 years. I understand that these increases were introduced as a result of promises made at election time. We believe that they are generally warranted.

However, one point that needs to be drawn to the Government's attention in this regard is the growing gap between the unemployment benefit and the tertiary education assistance scheme allowance. The Budget deliberately restricted the TEAS increase but increased, very significantly, the unemployment benefit in a number of ways. That is somewhat contrary to the very precise statements made by the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) when in opposition. I quote from a statement that she made in October 1981:
It seems to us in the Labor Party and, I think also to the Australian Democrats , that the Government's--
that is, the Fraser Government's-
strategy of forcing students out of full time study and on to the dole is totally irrational and indefensible . . .
She went on:

While ever there is such a disparity between the level of payment available for unemployment benefit and the level of assistance for full time students, students from modest backgrounds will from time to time be forced out of universities and tertiary institutions and on to the dole. How the Government can possibly defend and maintain that system really defies rational understanding.

It seems to me that this growing gap flies right in the face of those remarks. It is a very strange decision for the Government to make, given the very fervent commitment on the part of the Education Minister to that idea. In fact, whereas we should have seen some attempt to rationalise the differences between the unemployment benefit and the tertiary education allowance, there has obviously been no attempt whatsoever to do that. We wonder why. We hope that the Minister will be able to explain the circumstances when there was such a firm commitment given in 1981 by the now Minister. I also point to another quote from Senator Ryan made a little earlier in 1981. She said:

I think that while this positive financial incentive to go on the dole exists, the Government's claims that it is really serious about reducing youth unemployment are shown to be absolutely hypocritical. There ought not to be such a positive financial incentive.

I think it is worth putting that on record too because again it demonstrates the very vehement feelings on the part of this Government, when it was in opposition , about this matter. Yet when given the opportunity, it has not sought to redress the point at all. We believe that is a significant matter which ought to be addressed if the Government is at all serious in its commitment along the lines of Senator Ryan's thinking, as I have just quoted it.

I turn now to the most important objection to the Bill that the Opposition has, which we will be pursuing at later stages of this Bill, in order to defeat if possible the passage of clauses 30 (2) and 30 (3). That amendment I believe, if it has not yet been circularised, will be in the not too distant future. The purpose of the Government in this Bill is to reinstate a position which existed before October 1979 whereby unemployment benefits were paid to certain categories of employees either as a result of action being taken by unionists outside the work place of those people or as a result of union action on the part of another union in that work place.

In 1979 the Fraser Government amended the social security legislation to provide that indeed that would not be the situation, that unemployment benefits would not be payable in those circumstances and would certainly not be available in the event of strikes being brought on and people having to be stood down in their present work place as a result of that particular industrial action. The point is one of very major principle. Trade unions may disdain responsibility for calling a strike in the first place to ensure that their members are not affected by loss of income as a result of the strike; yet they can cause maximum disruption to the economy and to the community generally as a result of activities such as I have outlined. In fact they seek to protect unionists against the effects of their own decisions. In other words, they lay off the cost of strike pay on the taxpayer. For that reason and because we were very keen to introduce those amendments in 1979, which of course were part of a total package of industrial legislation which affected amendments to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act as well, we will be pursuing that matter to a greater degree during the Committee stage.

I think we need to draw the Senate's attention to some of the reasons why we feel so strongly about this. It is true that, if industrial action can be called virtually at any time with protection for all striking employees in the circumstances outlined in the legislation, clearly there is no sanction against the leadership of unions which can be exercised by employees. We believe that in order to introduce responsibility into the affairs of trade unions individual members unions should have the right, and indeed should be encouraged to exercise that right, of control over the union leadership. Obviously, this is a democratic idea. Obviously, because of the Government's present action in moving to introduce this legislation, it is something to which the Government is not committed. But it is a point that we feel particularly concerned about because it not only affects individuals and the broader community, or even members of parliament, who may be affected by strikes but also goes to the very heart of our current economic problems. I think all of us here would recognise that our present situation revolves very largely around the difficulties of the employed. If very powerful union muscle is used against the employers, and thereby of couse governments and indeed the community generally, in such a way as to force wage increases from the community, the benefits flow to unionists, in employment ; they do not flow to people who are not in employment. We on this side have the view that if the Government is truly compassionate about the unemployed, is truly concerned about the way in which the economy should work and is truly concerned about issues of wage restraint it should be seeking to control as much as possible the power and the muscle of trade unions in forcing wage claims out of this economy rather than moving in the other direction by allowing fewer sanctions and thereby introducting a more lenient approach to the trade unions. That is our concern because we see the economic issue of today being very closely bound up with this problem of union power. It is one which we would hope the Government will have the opportunity of thinking about should our amendment be carried in the Committee stage. We believe it is one of such vital principle, right at this time when the economy in such disarray, that it needs to be brought right home to the Government that the community is in a state of very great concern about the degree of union muscle and the way in which that power is being exercised to the detriment of not only the broad community but particularly those who are unemployed. We believe that that deserves the support of all honourable senators, and we will certainly be seeking the support of the Australian Democrats and the Independent in this place for our amendment.

There are one or two other issues that I would just like to touch on as we are now running out of time. I would like to return to that matter at some later stage of the debate. I will quickly refer to the amendments in the legislation in respect of friendly societies. Under this legislation income they provide to their members will be included, for the purposes of determining eligibility for the service pension and for the age pension, in the income test provisions as they presently apply. The Opposition is not opposing that measure in any way, but we draw attention to the fact that friendly societies are a very significant group and have been serving purposes far beyond those things which are the subject of these amendments. We believe that they have a very relevant place in the community. We have not as yet seen statements or any legislation from the Government in respect of what has been breathed about-possible taxation changes for friendly societies. We will be looking at those in great detail and with a great deal of interest if the Government decides to proceed with them.

In respect of the delegations and the matters of technical concern in relation to the affairs of the Department of Social Security and the relationship between officers and the Director-General, I have only one matter to bring to the attention of the Senate. In recent months the Government has issued questionnaires to people over the age of 70 seeking information on their assets, ostensibly with the object of assessing their eligibility for the age pension on the basis of the present income test. As part of the declaration at the foot of the questionnaires was an authorisation for the Department to obtain whatever information was required from various sources. If the Government were confident about its legal situation in that regard I would have thought that it would not have sought any authorisation on the part of the person who was going to be now treated in this way by virtue of the questionnaire by seeking the person to sign an authority of that kind.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Cape Flattery Silica Mine-Australian Broadcasting Corporation News Service

PROCTEXT.PARA: Cape Flattery Silica Mine-Australian Broadcasting Corporation News Service

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 6.30 p.m., pursuant to sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak this evening on an issue of grave concern relating to Aborigines in far north Queensland. Some of my colleagues may be aware of an Australian Broadcasting Corporation Nationwide report in Queensland last night. This program highlighted the conditions of Aboriginal workers at the Cape Flattery silica mine in far north Queensland. Workers from the Hopevale Aboriginal community have been on strike for approximately ten days because of blatant racism practised by the management of this Mitsubishi mine. Interviews with Aboriginal workers revealed that unionism is being actively discouraged at the Cape Flattery mine. Workers do not have access to their terms of employment, as contracts were negotiated by the company and the paternalistic Queensland Department of Aboriginal and Islanders Advancement. Furthermore, workers reported discrimination in the allocation of jobs, with those with the darkest skins being graded into the most unpleasant tasks. Aboriginal workers are forced to live in single accommodation at the mine site, and this is despite the fact that married quarters are provided for their white counterparts.

SPEECH.PARA: There appears to be a great deal of secrecy surrounding the terms of the lease negotiated for the operation of Cape Flattery Mines Pty Ltd and this secrecy is of grave concern particularly, I think, to this chamber. The people of Hopevale report that the area was excised from the reserve and that the Department of Aboriginal and Islanders Advancement has control over any royalties paid. While it is understood that the Hopevale people were to benefit from this venture, no one knows just what royalties have been paid. This applies to the Hopevale community council, a body, one would have thought, that would have been consulted by the Department of Aboriginal and Islanders Advancement in Queensland. But apparently these details are highly confidential and remain totally in the control of the Director of the Department of Aboriginal and Islanders Advancement, now a National Party candidate in the forthcoming Queensland election, a Mr Pat Killoran. All of these issues are of the utmost concern to the people of Hopevale and I trust that the Nationwide program will be successful in forcing the Queensland Government and others to answer these grievances.

However, the point I wish to raise as a very special additional concern expressed by some Cape Flattery workers is one that was not discussed on the program last night and one which I think should have the attention of this chamber. The potential risk of the disease silicosis is one that concerns me. Silicosis is a disease brought about by a fine dust settling on the lungs over a considerable period. It would appear that this is possibly a great risk at Cape Flattery. Several workers have reported severe discomfort from working at the silica mine. It has been claimed that adequate health and safety measures are not practised continuously at Cape Flattery. I understand, for instance, that protective goggles should be worn by workers to protect their eyes from the intense glare brought about by the brilliant white sand. This is not always the case. Furthermore, I understand that protective breathing apparatus should be introduced for those workers handling the silica sand, particularly in the enclosed areas of ships' holds during loading. My reports are that this is not always the case. There appears to be no evidence of any special health checks and no effort has apparently been made by either the Queensland Government or the Mitsubishi company to monitor potential health risk by means of regular chest x-rays. Overseas studies have revealed that there is considerable concern about the effects of industrial silica dust on workers' health. Studies also reveal variation in response to exposure to industrial silica dust, depending on individual health characteristics and the length of time those workers are in contact with silica dust. I consulted a doctor in far north Queensland over the weekend and he advised me that Aborigines do have a higher than average rate of lung disorders. Therefore, it would seem vital that immediate steps be taken to screen Cape Flattery workers from the Hopevale community. I am extremely concerned about the potential health risk at the Cape Flattery mine and I will be making representations to the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) and to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) to have the appropriate Federal Government department investigate these issues as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the past 50 years, the Australian Broadcasting Commission-now a restructured Corporation-has established a reputation, world-wide, for the integrity and impartiality of its news service. There have been numerous occasions, of course, on which the impartiality of the programs section of the ABC has been called into question. We have all had experience of that. But through it all, down the years, the ABC news has remained to many Australians spread right throughout the country one of the great credible and impartial news services of this country. Now, under the Hawke Government, in cahoots with its Labor friends in the States, it seems that that is all about to change. It seems that if the Australian Labor Party has its way, we will have the quite incredible situation in which the Labor Party, through its connections in the communications Ministry and through that Ministry to the Corporation itself, will attempt to take unto itself special favoured treatment through the ABC news service to the disadvantage of the other parties. This is a direct threat to the impartiality and integrity of the national broadcasting service. That tactic is being tried, and openly admitted by the State Secretary of the Labor Party in Queensland, Mr Peter Beattie, in a desperate attempt by the Labor Party to influence the outcome of next week's State election in Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: For as long as the ABC news service has been functioning it has, down through the years, handled news coverage of events and comments by political parties, before an election, on the basis of news value and fairness. That is a principle that has been staunchly defended by professional journalists within the ABC news service for as long as the ABC has been functioning. Now, by a direct approach to the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) the Labor Party in Queensland has to change that. Based on the ALP approach, admitted by Mr Beattie, ABC journalists in Queensland have been issued, but have rejected, a directive that ABC political news coverage, in the last week leading to the State election be on the basis of a predetermined formula emanating from Canberra and, surprise, that formula just happens to favour the Australian Labor Party in Queensland to the disadvantage of the non-socialist parties. The formula sets out a daily lineage rate under which the Labor Opposition in Queensland would receive almost twice as much ABC news coverage as the National Party Government and also about twice the coverage of the Liberal Party. The Australian Democrats do not even get a mention in the formula and directive. My advice is that this amazing directive, quite unprecedented in the 50 years of the national broadcasting service, stemmed directly from an approach by the Labor Opposition leader in Queensland, Mr Keith Wright, to the Minister for Communications in Canberra. The Labor Party is not admitting that, but Mr Beattie concedes that an approach did take place. He has admitted so publicly in the Brisbane Sunday Sun of last Sunday, 16 October.

This is evidence of attempted political interference of the most serious kind in the operations of this country's independent national broadcasting service. It represents a gross misuse of the national broadcasting service for which the Minister for Communications, as a party to it, must be removed from office to restore public confidence in the integrity and impartiality of the ABC. To their credit, ABC journalists in Brisbane, at a special meeting of their House Committee, rejected this attempted interference and are refusing to obey the directive. These people are to be commended for their personal courage and integrity in taking this stand. It is an indictment on the Hawke Government and the way things in government are going in this country that these journalists should ever be tested or have to face such pressures from an incumbent government. It has never happened before.

The resolution carried by the Australian Journalists Association House Committee, at the ABC in Brisbane, objected strongly to the news directive on the grounds that such interference threatens the integrity and the independence of the news department. It reaffirmed the ABC news department's long standing policy of handling pre-election material from political parties on the basis of news value and fairness and balance through fair and, as far as possible, equal treatment. But that is not good enough for the Labor Party. It wants to be treated more fairly and more equally on its own directive. I would like to take the opportunity now to read a statement by the AJA that has been issued today. It states:

Queensland Branch President Ken Blanch said in a news release today journalists should reject any management attempt to impose the ratios.

The code required journalists to report the news with scrupulous honesty and prohibit the distortion of trust by omission or wrongful emphasis.

'It would be unethical for any journalist to ignore a genuine news story because one party had already filled its arbitrary quota or to broadcast a suspect story to pad out the time for another party,' Mr Blanch said.
The only criterion should be the traditional test of news value, he said.

The ABC's acting controller of news, David Prior, said yesterday he had told Brisbane news staff to aim for a ratio of about 43 per cent air time for Labor and 28 per cent each for the Liberal and National parties, in proportion to the vote they attracted at the last election.

The actions which followed Mr Keith Wright's approach to Canberra have involved ABC officials from the Deputy General Manager down. This sort of political pressure must not go unchallenged by this Parliament. Action should be taken to ensure that it never happens again. It was publicly stated by Mr Justin Hickey, who by then was Sir Justin Hickey, that, for a contribution of $100,000 to the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation, Mr Hickey, being a resident of the State of New South Wales, could get a knighthood; and, said Sir Justin Hickey, he put in the $100,000 and he got the knighthood. Those are the sorts of standards with which we are dealing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr President. I think that the $100 ,000 to which the honourable senator is referring was a donation to a nursing home. I think that that is the donation to which he is referring. It is the only one that I know about.
—You ought to read the Standing Orders.
—Order! That is a point of view. It is not a point of order.

—This is the party to which Senator Boswell belongs. That is the sort of record that it has. It is a party which believes in public funding of election campaigns, public funding of the party which happens to be in control of government, which is currently spending millions of dollars, misappropriating and misspending millions of Queensland taxpayers' dollars in crude advertising campaigns, disguised as Government advertising campaigns, designed to save the seats of the assorted mediocrities promoted into the Bjelke-Petersen Cabinet following the collapse of the coalition Government. That the National Party should throw such smears and should attempt to intimidate news media in the way in which it has today is in keeping with its record.
—We have not intimidated; you intimidated. You are the one who has told us what to do--
—Order!

—It is also indicative, a measure of its desperation. The Bjelke- Petersen Government is about to pass into history. Bjelke-Petersen, the greatest political barracouta that this country has seen this century--
—Order! I ask the Minister to withdraw that remark.
—In deference to you, Mr President, I withdraw.
—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. Surely a withdrawal has to be without conditions, without any other words attached.
—I ask the Minister to withdraw.

—I withdraw, Mr President. As regards Bjelke-Petersen, it is becoming increasingly apparent-and I am surprised that Senator Peter Baume sees fit to defend him; perhaps he was just defending the Standing Orders--
—That is all.

—It would surprise me if any self-respecting member of the Liberal Party-and I have always regarded Senator Peter Baume as being such-would in any way seek to defend the Bjelke-Petersen regime. The Bjelke-Petersen regime is about to follow the dodo-or perhaps, in the evolutionary scale, the dinosaurs would be a more appropriate term-into political extinction in three days or four days time, and this unsubstantiated, inaccurate--
—It is not unsubstantiated.
—Order!

—This unsubstantiated, inaccurate and historically unsupportable series of allegations made here tonight by Senator Boswell and evidently made earlier today in the House of Representatives is a fair measure of the desperation of that regime, thrashing about in a desperate last ditch attempt to save itself from the extinction which it faces on Saturday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not aware that Senator Boswell would be raising this matter in the Senate this evening.
—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. Was the Minister closing the debate on the adjournment?
—No. There is no point of order.

—I will start again, Mr President. I was not aware that Senator Boswell would be raising this matter in the Senate this evening. It seemed to me that what was said in the House of Representatives this afternoon put this story at rest. The Minister for Communications, Mr Duffy, made a statement about it and refuted the allegations which were brought forward in the House of Representatives and the allegations which have been parroted to the Senate by Senator Boswell. I was also aware of the fact that legal action was to be taken against Sir Robert Sparkes and perhaps the secretary of the National Party in Queensland. I was therefore very surprised when Senator Boswell thought fit to come forward and repeat what had been said in the lower House and refuted there.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that the National Party has singled out Senator Boswell as its hatchet man in the Senate. It certainly could not give the prepared speech to Senator Flo Bjelke-Petersen, because she is not here today. She is up in Queensland electioneering for the National Party. She has some idea that it might be possible to save the National Party, so she is up there. I wonder whether the Senate knows what she did today. She took fresh pumpkin scones down to the miners in Ipswich who are having a sit-in. There she is, on television in Queensland tonight with her fresh pumpkin scones.

Senator Boswell has been lined up as the hatchet man. I give him a little warning. There was another National Party senator in this chamber who was once lined up as the hatchet man-not to do what Senator Boswell did tonight, but to do something out in the electorate. We know what happened to him. He got on the skids. He never got into the House of Representatives. He was looking forward to getting into it. He never got back into this place, either, when he put his name forward as a person to fill his own casual vacancy.

We have become fairly used to something in Queensland, and it has become folklore around the place; that is, the malapportionment of electorates in Queensland, or the gerrymander as it is often called. This will change when Labor becomes the government after the elections on Saturday. But the National Party is upset. It can gerrymander the electorates in Queensland, but it cannot manipulate the Press. This is the sort of rubbish that comes across here this evening. Tomorrow Senator Boswell can be assured that when people are able to come in here with all the facts that were presented in the House of Representatives this afternoon-something we have not been able to gather; we have just been able to gleen them at this stage-if he keeps raising these sorts of matters, the real truth will be thrown back at him. He ought to be sure of his facts before he comes in here.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was.

—If Senator Boswell wants a lesson in the Standing Orders, I tell him to get into his own place if he is going to interject. He does not even know the first thing about what is going on in this place and he comes in here with a pack of untruths that have been presented to him and tries to deliver them before the Senate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, upon notice , on 23 August 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Why does the Government not recognise de facto relationships for the purpose of providing a basis for eligibility for independent status under the tertiary education assistance scheme-TEAS.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: There are a number of aspects of the tertiary education assistance scheme-TEAS- including the previous Government's decision that de facto relationships should no longer provide a basis for eligibility for independent status, which might be reviewed but which the Government would not wish to consider piecemeal but rather as part of a broad review of the program. The likely cost of such changes would also have to be taken into account. My Department has already commenced a general examination of TEAS conditions with a view to submitting proposals to me for consideration in the 1984-85 Budget.
