QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 25 August 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When did the continual difficulties with amphibian vehicles, referred to in the Department of Transport and Construction 1981-82 annual report page 40, become apparent.
(2) How much has been spent rectifying these problems in each of the last seven years.
(3) How much of the cost relates to labour cost in the Department's Victorian workshop.
(4) How many of these vehicles does the Department own.
(5) How many of these vehicles are owned by other departments.
(6) Have other owners experienced similar problems; if so, what liaison has been established between other departments to overcome these mutual problems.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The difficulties referred to relate to problems in obtaining spare parts which arose during the latter part of the 1970s. The amphibian vehicles used by the Department are the LARC V type manufactured in the United States. This type of vehicle is also used by the Australian Army from which the Department obtains spare parts.

(2) Because of the difficulties with spares for the transmission system the Department undertook investigations into modifying the transmission system of one of the amphibians. About $125,000 has been spent on this project which could provide the basis for converting other LARCS should the need arise. However, the difficulties with spare parts now appear to have been overcome, at least for the time being.
(3) Approximately $25,000 of the cost has been attributed to labour in the Department's Victorian workshop.
(4) The Department owns nine amphibian vehicles.
(5) As far as I am aware the Department of Defence is the only other Commonwealth department which owns LARC V amphibians. I understand that it owns about 80 of these vehicles.

(6) I understand that the Department of Defence has experienced similar difficulties. My Department has maintained a close liaison with the Department of Defence on the question of spare parts. The Australian Army has been conducting a review of the supportability and operation of LARCS up to 1990. My Department expects to receive the results of this review in the near future.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 13 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Army Reserve pay matched exactly to the Regular Army pay and then is approximately one-third deducted so that the Army Reserve gross pay matches the Regular Army 'take-home' pay; if so, does this mean the Army Reserve wages will be subjected to a form of double-taxation under the Government's recent decision to tax Army Reserve pay.
(2) Will this new measure have any effect on the number of people attracted to the Army Reserve.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The short answer is no. In 1975 pay and allowances for the reserve forces were reviewed by the Committee of Reference for Defence Force Pay which concluded that there was an inequality of skill, efficiency and professionalism between the regular and reserve forces which should be reflected in differing rates of pay, but that the inequality in rates should be more marginal than substantial. The pay relationship was last quantified by the Committee of Reference in August 1982 as follows:
(a) Officers of the ranks of 2nd Lieutenant to Major and equivalent ranks in the other two Services-90 per cent of the permanent Force salary for equivalent rank; and
(b) Officers of the ranks of Lieutenant-Colonel and above, and equivalent ranks in the other two Services, and all other rank members-85 per cent of the permanent force salary for equivalent rank.

(2) I believe that provided the rates of pay and allowances are equitable recompense for the commitment required of members, a tax exemption is not an essential ingredient for attracting sufficient members into the reserve forces.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 6 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Australian Government now have a greater responsibility under the ANZUS alliance for regional defence as a result of the recent ANZUS Minister's meeting in Washington; if so, what action is the Government taking to fulfill that greater responsibility.

(2) Does Australia need to strengthen its defence capability in the light of the Washington communique; if so, how is this reconcilable with the Government's abandonment of the fixed wing elements of the Navy's Fleet Air Arm and the Government's decision not to purchase an aircraft carrier.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I refer the honourable senator to the parliamentary statement, made by my colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs on 15 September 1983, which reported the outcome of the ANZUS Council meeting and the review of the ANZUS Treaty undertaken with our partners.

(2) Carrying responsibility for our own security requires that priorities are clearly defined and resources allocated for maximum effect. Those priorities led to the decision not to acquire an aircraft carrier. A range of weapons systems which the Defence Force either has now or is planning to acquire can effectively perform the roles in which an aircraft carrier might have contributed. These weapons systems, combined with other improvements (planned and in progress) such as upgraded airfields, provide capabilities that a small carrier's aircraft could not remotely match.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 5 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Is any restriction placed on the quality of a denture supplied to a person on a war widow's pension, the quality of any of the components of a denture, or the fee paid to a dentist who supplies such a denture; if so, what are the restrictions and, if there are no restrictions in relation to the dentures, what action can be taken where a dentist supplies a substandard denture.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: There are no restrictions on quality of dentures as long as the dentist accepts payment at government approved rates.
The only restriction on components of dentures is that prior departmental approval is necessary for 'cobalt-chromium' type dentures.

In the event that a beneficiary complains about dentures, arrangements are made to obtain a report from the local dental officer and to have the patient examined by the Department's Consultant (Dental Services) in the State concerned . If the denture is considered sub-standard, payment of fee may be refused and arrangements made for a new denture.

The Department has a comprehensive range of dental fees for service of which all local dental officers are aware. The dentist bills the Department according to the applicable fee for the type of denture provided. The fee for service is approved by the Government and agreed with the Australian Dental Association.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 September 1983 (Hansard, page 859), Senator Watson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology a question without notice concerning government support for high technology and referring specifically to the proposed reduction of 80 personnel within the Defence Science and Technology Organisation.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(1) The external review of the Defence Science and Technology organisation ( DSTO) which was completed in October 1980 made a number of recommendations to redress the effects of decreasing resources. The thrust of some of these recommendations-and the Government endorses this thrust-was that there was a need to:
(a) Provide adequate operating resources for DSTO scientists and engineers; and
(b) Replace obsolete DSTO plant over a period of time.

(1) Resources available to DSTO have had to be constrained in the light of overall defence priorities in a period of tightly controlled defence expenditure overall. This constraint has led to a situation where the support funds available to the DSTO scientists and engineers were falling below levels judged necessary for effective research and development activity.

(3) It was therefore decided that some reductions would be made in the manpower resources for the DSTO in exchange for increased allocations for operating costs and minor capital funds. Manning reductions of about 80 positions out of a total of about 4,500 are being made in 1983-84 by selective non-replacement of natural staff wastage. There will be no retrenchments.
(4) This will increase the effectiveness of DSTO in most areas, but as a result of the staff reductions work in some lower priority areas will be curtailed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 September 1983 (Hansard, page 739), Senator Watson asked me a question, without notice, concerning research in Australia into utilising hydrogen as a source of energy, and Government incentives for such research.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

The 'Compendium of Australian Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Projects', published by my Department, identifies four hydrogen projects currently in progress in Australia. These are in the areas of hydrogen production using solar energy, hydrogen storage and processing, and the use of hydrogen as a vehicle fuel. Most of the funding for these projects has been provided by the Commonwealth through the national energy research, development and demonstration (NERD and D) program. Between 1978 and 1982 $462,115 was committed under the program.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 September 1983 (Hansard, page 590), Senator Missen asked a question concerning a report by the London-based Anti-Slavery Society for the Protection of Human Rights concerning alleged human rights abuses of the Melanesian population of Irian Jaya. In my reply I outlined the nature of the Indonesian Government's transmigration program in Irian Jaya and international efforts to protect the rights of indigenous peoples. I also noted that Australia has played an active role in focusing international attention to this issue.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following additional information:
The Anti-Slavery Society for the Protection of Human Rights plans to publish reports on its findings in Irian Jaya within the next 12 months.

Until that report is published, the Society's statement to the United Nations Working Group on Indigenous Populations in Geneva is the most definitive account of the Society's views. A copy of the society's statement is available from Mr Hayden's office.

It is difficult to obtain accurate figures on the number of transmigrants who have gone to Irian Jaya as target figures are often not realised. However, according to the Indonesian Department of Transmigration, 58,000 people had been transferred to the province as at the end of August 1983.
In addition to transmigrants, there are also another 100,000-160,000 unsponsored migrants in Irian Jaya.

According to a study by Professor Arndt of the Australian National University, transmigration to Irian Jaya during the Indonesian Government's current third five-year development plan (1979-1984) represents around 4.3 per cent of total official transmigrants. This compares with 60.6 per cent settled in Sumatra, 20. 2 per cent in Kalimantan and 12.3 per cent in Sulawesi.
